revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1854 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Baseball]]== '''Events''' * The [[New York Knickerbockers|Knickerbockers]] adopt some rule changes agreed in conference by their delegates with those of the Gothams and Eagles. * The Eagles win their first two matches, with the Knickerbockers in mid-November, 21–4 and 22–21. The latter is the first time one team scores 21 but loses in "equal innings".
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * [[Harry Broome]] retains the Championship of England but there is no record of any fights involving him in 1851.<ref name="HB">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/broome-h.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Harry Broome]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref> * American champion [[John Morrissey]] becomes involved in Democratic politics in New York City and from this develops a bitter rivalry with [[William Poole]], also known as "Bill the Butcher", another prizefighter. Poole is also the leader of a notorious gang called the Bowery Boys who plan to seize ballot boxes and rig an election. Morrissey and others are hired to prevent this.<ref name="JM">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/morrisey.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – John Morrissey]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref> * 14 February — [[Tom Paddock]] defeats [[Harry Poulson]] at Mildenhall in 102 rounds; this is the third and effectively deciding bout between the two.<ref name="TP">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/paddock.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Tom Paddock]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref> * 18 July — Paddock defeats [[Aaron Jones (boxer)|Aaron Jones]] at Long Reach in 121 rounds.<ref name="TP"/> * 26 July — Poole and Morrisey agree to fight each other at Amos Dock, New York, to settle their dispute. Morrissey is badly beaten and, worried about the presence of Poole's supporters, concedes defeat.<ref name="JM"/> * 27 August — Tom Paddock issues challenges to English Champion [[Harry Broome]] and to former champion [[William Perry (boxer)|William Perry]] but both refuse. Paddock responds by claiming the Championship of England, but he is not recognised at this time.<ref name="TP"/> * 20 October — Morrissey declines a challenge for his American title from retired former champion [[Tom Hyer]]. It will be exactly four years until Morrissey defends his title again.<ref name="JM"/>
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * The follow-on differential is reduced to 80 (or 60 in one day). '''England''' * Most runs – [[Jemmy Dean]] 516 @ 16.12 (HS 99) * Most wickets – [[John Wisden]] 106 @ 9.83 (BB 8–41)
==[[Football]]== '''Events''' * [[Dublin University Football Club]] is founded by students at [[Trinity College, Dublin|Trinity College]]. It is a [[rugby union]] club still based in the college grounds and plays in the [[AIB League]]. It is the world's [[Oldest football clubs|oldest extant football club]] (all codes) in terms of continuous existence.
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1854 Grand National|Grand National]] – Bourton * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Virago (horse)|Virago]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – The Hermit * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Andover (horse)|Andover]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Mincemeat * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – Knight of St George
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 8 April — [[Oxford University Boat Club|Oxford]] wins the 12th [[The Boat Race 1854|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]], last contested in 1852
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1851 – 1900}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1854 in sports| ]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Use Australian English|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox | above = 1870 Victorian football season | label1 = Senior teams | data1= 5 | label2 = Premiers | data2 = {{AFL Mel}} | label3 = [[Challenge Cup (Australia)|Challenge Cup]] | data3 = [[Albert Park Football Club (VFA)|Albert-park]] ''(disputed)'' |below = {{align|left|}} {{align|right|[[1871 Victorian football season|1871]] →}} }}
The '''1870 Victorian football season''' was an [[Australian rules football]] competition played during the winter of 1870, consisting of matches between metropolitan football clubs in Melbourne in the colony of Victoria. The premier club was {{AFL Mel}}.
==Historical status== By convention, the 1870 season is considered the first season of senior football competition in Victoria's history, or at least the first for which a premiership can be officially allocated. The reasons for this are somewhat arbitrary, since the competing clubs, organizational structure of football, and standard of play in 1870 were not materially different from 1869.
The view of 1870 as being the inaugural premiership has existed since at least 1889, when ''The Argus'' newspaper first published a table of historical premiers and second and third place-getters dating back to 1870 and no earlier. In the article which adjoined the publication of the 1889 table, the reporter commented that the haphazard nature of scheduling, frequency of cancelled matches, and overall lesser standard of play made it difficult to assign a premiership to the seasons during the 1860s.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Argus|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|page=5|title=The Football Premiership|date=23 September 1889}}</ref>
The VFL's official publication, the ''[[Football Record]]'', also showed this same list from its inception in 1912 until 1918. In 1919, this was replaced with a new table that showed club placings since 1897, and two supplementary tables showing cumulated placings for the periods 1897 to 1918 and 1870 to 1918. These supplementary tables remained in the Record until 1923, but were omitted from the 1924 editions of the Record, and did not reappear after that.<ref name="agebackdate">{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/afl/afl-news/history-of-the-afl-could-be-turned-on-its-head-20140620-zsglu.html|title=History of the AFL could be turned on its head|date=20 June 2014|accessdate=18 October 2014|author=Caroline Wilson|work=[[The Age]]|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC}}</ref> <ref> [http://australianfootball.com/articles/view/rethinking+the+historical+record/161 Rethinking the historical record] </ref>
Since June 2016, the [[AFL Commission]] has formally recognised the top level of Victorian football back to 1870 as senior, which applies to both the unaffiliated period from 1870–1876 and the [[Victorian Football Association]] from 1877–1896. However, it maintains a distinction between the 1870–1896 competitions and the history of the [[Australian Football League|VFL/AFL]] from 1897 onwards, and requires statistics and achievements from those two periods to be delineated; <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afl.com.au/news/2016-06-09/afl-knocks-back-cats-bid-for-extra-flags|title=AFL knocks back Cats' bid for extra flags|accessdate=9 June 2016|publisher=Australian Football League|author=Travis King}}</ref> at the same time, the Commission allowed clubs to recognise these achievements in their own histories. <ref>[http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/sport/afl/teams/port-adelaide/afl-commission-accepts-all-clubs-can-acknowledge-their-success-from-outside-the-vflafl-competition/news-story/d7ab969dff3bfe01e75933e899e8b87a AFL Commission will allow clubs to recognise their history outside the VFL/AFL] </ref>
==1870 season== Five clubs participated in senior football during the 1870 season: [[Albert Park Football Club (VFA)|Albert-park]], {{AFL Car}}, [[Melbourne and Hobson's Bay Railway Company|Hobson's Bay Railway]], {{AFL Mel}} and South Yarra. They competed in specific matches for the Challenge Cup, and a premier team was selected based on all matches during the season, including Challenge Cup matches.
===Challenge Cup=== In 1870, the South Yarra Football Club purchased and put up a new trophy, known as the [[Challenge Cup (Australia)|Challenge Cup]] (or sometimes as the South Yarra Presentation Challenge Cup, to differentiate it from other challenge cups donated by different organisations), for competition. South Yarra was the permanent holder of the previous Challenge Cup, and decided it would be appropriate to provide a new trophy for competition. The rules relating to the presentation of the new Challenge Cup were as follows:<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Australasian|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|page=652|author=|date=21 May 1870|volume=VIII|issue=216|title=The South Yarra Presentation Challenge Cup}}</ref> *South Yarra would be the initial holder of the cup. *Any match between the holder of the cup and another senior team would be played for the cup. *In a cup match, the winner of the match would take possession of the cup, and the incumbent holder would retain the cup in the event of a draw. *A club would become the permanent holder of the cup if it won the cup four times in a row without a loss (but with no limit on the number of drawn games during that streak); until that time, the cup would remain a perpetual award. Other stipulations relating to Challenge Cup games were that they were required to be controlled by central umpires, rather than by the team captains, and that no player was allowed to play for more than one club in Challenge Cup games during the year.
[[Albert Park Football Club (VFA)|Albert-park]] took possession of the Cup in the first game against South Yarra, and never relinquished it. However, the fate of the Cup became controversial when Hobson's Bay Railway forfeited its 11 June match against Albert-park due to lack of players. Railway declined to play when only fourteen of its selected twenty turned up on the day of the game,<ref name="railwayresponse">{{cite news|newspaper=The Australasian|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|page=332|author=J. Hacker (honorary secretary of the Hobson's Bay Railway Football Club)|date= 10 September 1870|volume=IX|issue=232|title=The "walk-over" and the Challenge Cup}}</ref> and Albert-park took to the field and scored two goals against no opposition as a [[walk-over#sports|walk-over]] formality.<ref name="walkover" /> Albert-park claimed the walk-over as its second Cup victory, and consequently claimed permanent possession of the Cup with its fourth win of the year on 20 August, but South Yarra, as cup donors, and several other clubs argued that the walk-over should have counted as a cancelled match rather than an Albert-park victory, and that another win was needed to claim permanent ownership of the Cup.<ref name="cancelled" /> Albert-park argued that enough procedural requirements, such as the appointment of umpires and the pre-game coin toss, had been carried out for the game to be considered official<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Australasian|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|page=300|author=C. Crooke (treasurer of Albert-park Football Club)|date=3 September 1870|volume=IX|issue=231|title=Albert-park v. Railway}}</ref> – Railway denied that these procedures had been carried out<ref name="railwayresponse" /> – and Albert-park argued that it was entitled to claim victory because Railway had declined the options of playing short or fielding other club officials or members who were present. Albert-park's position in claiming victory on a technicality was considered to be against the spirit of competition. There was no specific rule regarding walk-overs written into the rules which could be used to resolve the dispute.<ref name="cancelled" />
Ultimately, the dispute was unresolved. There was no central body which could make a binding ruling on whether or not the walk-over counted as a victory, and neither side conceded its opponent's point. Albert-park played only one further game for the season, a draw against {{AFL Mel}}, but it refused to put the Cup up for contest in the match. It is also noted that Albert-park was denied the chance to become the undisputed permanent holder of the Cup on 6 August, when its return match with the weak Railway club was cancelled due to inclement weather.<ref name="cancelled" />
Albert-park ultimately gave the Cup back to South Yarra at the end of the year, but maintained its position that it had won the Cup outright and was donating it in its capacity as the Cup's owner.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Australasian|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|page=492|author=Fair Play|date=15 October 1870|volume=IX|issue=237|title=Football – retrospect of the season}}</ref> South Yarra maintained its position that Albert-park had not won the Cup, and had forfeited its position as incumbent holder.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Australasian|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|page=684|author=|date=3 June 1871|volume=X|issue=270|title=The Challenge Cup}}</ref>
The following table lists the final results of all Challenge Cup games. {{AFLGameHeader|title=1870 Challenge Cup games}} {{AFLGame|Saturday, 28 May|South Yarra|1|A|[[Albert Park Football Club (VFA)|Albert-park]]|3|[[St Kilda Cricket Ground]]||<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Australasian|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|page=716|author=Fair Play|date=4 June 1870|volume=VIII|issue=218|title=Football}}</ref>}} {{AFLGame|Saturday, 4 June|[[Albert Park Football Club (VFA)|Albert-park]]|0{{ref|1|Note}}|D|{{AFL Mel}}|0|Emerald Hill Ground|1,500|<ref name="headcount">{{cite news|newspaper=The Australasian|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|page=748|author=Fair Play|date=11 June 1870|volume=VIII|issue=219|title=Football}}</ref>}} {{AFLGame|''Saturday, 11 June ([[walk-over]], disputed)''|''[[Albert Park Football Club (VFA)|Albert-park]]''||H|''Hobson's Bay Railway''||''Emerald Hill Ground''||<ref name="walkover">{{cite news|newspaper=The Australasian|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|page=779|author=Fair Play|date=18 June 1870|volume=VIII|issue=220|title=Football}}</ref>}} {{AFLGame|Saturday, 18 June|{{AFL Car}}|0|D|[[Albert Park Football Club (VFA)|Albert-park]]|0|[[Royal Park, Melbourne|Royal Park]]||<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Australasian|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|page=812|author=Fair Play|date=25 June 1870|volume=VIII|issue=221|title=Football}}</ref>}} {{AFLGame|Saturday, 9 July|[[Albert Park Football Club (VFA)|Albert-park]]|2|H|South Yarra|1|Emerald Hill Ground|450|<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Australasian|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|page=43|author=|date=16 July 1870|volume=IX|issue=224|title=Football}}</ref>}} {{AFLGame|Saturday, 16 July|{{AFL Mel}}|0|D|[[Albert Park Football Club (VFA)|Albert-park]]|0|Melbourne Ground|2,500|<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Australasian|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|page=108|author=|date=23 July 1870|volume=IX|issue=225|title=Football}}</ref>}} {{AFLGame|Saturday, 23 July|[[Albert Park Football Club (VFA)|Albert-park]]|0|D|{{AFL Car}}|0|Emerald Hill Ground|3,000|<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Australasian|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|page=140|author=Fair Play|date=30 July 1870|volume=IX|issue=226|title=Football}}</ref>}} {{AFLGame|Saturday, 6 August (cancelled due to rain)|Hobson's Bay Railway||V|[[Albert Park Football Club (VFA)|Albert-park]]||Lonsdale Ground<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Australasian|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|page=173|author=|date=6 August 1870|volume=IX|issue=227|title=Football}}</ref>||<ref name="cancelled">{{cite news|newspaper=The Australasian|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|page=204|author=Fair Play|date=13 August 1870|volume=IX|issue=228|title=Football chatter}}</ref>}} {{AFLGame|Saturday, 13 August|[[Albert Park Football Club (VFA)|Albert-park]]|1|D|{{AFL Car}}|1|Emerald Hill Ground||<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Australasian|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|page=236|author=Fair Play|date=20 August 1870|volume=IX|issue=226|title=Football chatter}}</ref>}} {{AFLGame|Saturday, 20 August|South Yarra|0|A|[[Albert Park Football Club (VFA)|Albert-park]]|2|Melbourne Ground|2,500|<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Australasian|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|page=267|author=Fair Play|date=27 August 1870|volume=IX|issue=230|title=Football chatter}}</ref>}} {{AFLGameFooter}}
===Premiership=== Although it had claimed the Challenge Cup and was undefeated during the season, Albert-park was not recognised as the premier team of the 1870 season: instead, {{AFL Mel}}, which was also undefeated, was named as the premier. Melbourne had recorded more wins than Albert-park during the year and had played four games against {{AFL Car}} for two wins and two draws, while Albert-park's three matches against Carlton had been drawn and their on-field wins had come against the weak South Yarra club, giving Melbourne a better claim to the premier position.
It is noteworthy that Albert-park's claim to the Challenge Cup was helped in large part by the fact that it was the first team to play against South Yarra during the year. Had South Yarra played its first game against Melbourne, Melbourne would have been in a strong position to win the Challenge Cup as well as the premiership.
===Senior results===
The following table shows the five clubs' senior results during the year: all matches played amongst the five Challenge Cup teams, plus matches that Melbourne played against the Police and against the [[Royal Irish Regiment (1684–1922)|18th Royal Irish Regiment]]. Albert-park's disputed walk-over victory against Railway is not included in the table.
<center> {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center; font-size: 90%; width: 60%" |- | colspan="14" style="background: #EBEBEB;" | {| border="0" width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" |- style="background: #EBEBEB;" | width="25%" style="border: 0;" | | style="border: 0; font-size: 115%;" | '''1870 Senior Clubs' Results''' | width="25%" style="border: 0;" | |} |- style="text-align: center; font-size: 90%;" ! width="25" | No. !! width="120" | TEAM !! width="25" | P !! width="25" | W !! width="25" | L !! width="25" | D |- style="background: #CCFFCC;" | 1 | '''{{AFL Mel}} (P)''' | 11 | 7 | 0 | 4 |- | 2 | [[Albert Park Football Club (VFA)|Albert-park]] | 8 | 3 | 0 | 5 |- | 3 | {{AFL Car}} | 8 | 1 | 2 | 5 |- | | South Yarra | 4 | 0 | 4 | 0 |- | | Hobson's Bay Railway | 3 | 0 | 3 | 0 |- style="font-size: xx-small;" | colspan="4" | '''Key:''' P = Played, W = Won, L = Lost, D = Drawn, (P) = Premiers | colspan="2" | Source:<ref name="review">{{cite news|newspaper=The Australasian|publication-place=Melbourne, VIC|page=524|author=Fair Play|date=23 October 1870|volume=IX|issue=238|title=Football – retrospect of the season}}</ref> |}</center>
==Notable events== *{{note|1}}In its Challenge Cup game against {{AFL Mel}} on 4 June, Albert-park scored a goal in the first half, but it was later annulled after a head count discovered that Albert-park had 22 men instead of 20 on the field. The game ended in a 0–0 draw.<ref name="headcount" /> *The practice of stopping play at half-time and changing ends was first introduced in the game between {{AFL Mel}} and {{AFL Car}} on 11 June; prior to this, teams had changed ends after each goal was scored.<ref name="walkover" />
==External links== *[[History of Australian rules football in Victoria (1853-1900)]]

{{refimprove|date=December 2012}} The '''1972 [[Mr. Olympia]]''' contest was an [[International Federation of BodyBuilders|IFBB]] [[professional bodybuilding]] competition held in October {{Citation needed|date=January 2013}} 1972 at the [[Handelshof]] in [[Essen]], [[West Germany]]. It was the 8th Mr. Olympia competition held.
==Results==
{| class="wikitable" ! Place ! Prize ! Name
|- | 1 | $2,000 | {{flagicon|Austria}} [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.getbig.com/results/e-mroly.htm|title=Mr. Olympia Contest Results|publisher=getbig.com}}</ref>
|- | 2 | | {{flagicon|Cuba}} [[Sergio Oliva]]
|- | 3 | | {{flagicon|France}} [[Serge Nubret]]
|- | 4 | | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Frank Zane]]
|- | 5 | | {{flagicon|Italy}} [[Franco Columbu]]
|} 6 (france) Edmund Karolewicz
==Notable events==
*[[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] won his third consecutive Mr. Olympia title, tying the previous record held by [[Sergio Oliva]] *The winner was decided by seven judges, four voted for [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] and three voted for [[Sergio Oliva]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.mrolympia.com Mr. Olympia]

{{TennisEventInfo|2001|Idea Prokom Open| | date=23 – 29 July | edition=1st (men) / 4th (women) | category=[[ATP International Series|International Series]] (men)
[[WTA Tier III tournaments|Tier III]] (women) | surface=[[Clay court|Clay]] / outdoors | location=[[Sopot]], Poland | champms={{flagicon|ESP}} [[Tommy Robredo]] | champws={{flagicon|ESP}} [[Cristina Torrens Valero]] | champmd={{flagicon|AUS}} [[Paul Hanley (tennis)|Paul Hanley]] / {{flagicon|AUS}} [[Nathan Healey]] | champwd={{flagicon|RSA}} [[Joannette Kruger]] / {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Francesca Schiavone]] }} The '''2001 Idea Prokom Open''' was a combined men's and women's [[tennis]] tournament played on [[Clay court|outdoor clay courts]] in [[Sopot]] in [[Poland]] that was part of the [[ATP International Series|International Series]] of the [[2001 ATP Tour]] and of [[WTA Tier III tournaments|Tier III]] of the [[2001 WTA Tour]]. The tournament ran from 23 July through 29 July 2001. ==Finals== ===Men's Singles=== {{main|2001 Idea Prokom Open – Men's Singles}} {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Tommy Robredo]] defeated {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Albert Portas]] 1–6, 7–5, 7–6 (7–2) * It was Robredo's only title of the year and the 1st of his career. ===Women's Singles=== {{main|2001 Idea Prokom Open – Women's Singles}} {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Cristina Torrens Valero]] defeated {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Gala León García]] 6–2, 6–2 * It was Torrens Valero's only title of the year and the 4th of her career. ===Men's Doubles=== {{main|2001 Idea Prokom Open – Men's Doubles}} {{flagicon|AUS}} [[Paul Hanley (tennis)|Paul Hanley]] / {{flagicon|AUS}} [[Nathan Healey]] defeated {{flagicon|GEO|1990}} [[Irakli Labadze]] / {{flagicon|HUN}} [[Attila Sávolt]] 7–6 (12–10), 6–2 * It was Hanley's only title of the year and the 1st of his career. It was Healey's only title of the year and the 1st of his career. ===Women's Doubles=== {{main|2001 Idea Prokom Open – Women's Doubles}} {{flagicon|RSA}} [[Joannette Kruger]] / {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Francesca Schiavone]] defeated {{flagicon|UKR}} [[Yulia Beygelzimer]] / {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Anastasia Rodionova]] 6–4, 6–0 * It was Kruger's only title of the year and the 3rd of her career. It was Schiavone's only title of the year and the 1st of her career. {{Orange Warsaw Open tournaments}} {{2001 ATP Tour}} {{2001 WTA Tour}} [[Category:2001 ATP Tour|Idea Prokom Open]] [[Category:2001 WTA Tour|Idea Prokom Open]] [[Category:Orange Warsaw Open]] {{poland-sport-stub}} {{tennis-competition-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''50+1 rule''' ([[German language|German]]: ''50+1-Regel'') is an informal term used to refer to a clause in the regulations of the [[Deutsche Fußball-Liga]]. The clause states that, in order to obtain a license to compete in the [[Bundesliga]], a club must hold a majority of its own voting rights. The rule is designed to ensure that the club's members retain overall control, protecting clubs from the influence of external investors.
==Background== Prior to 1998, football clubs in Germany were owned exclusively by members' associations.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Schaerlaeckens|first1=Leander|title=The best league in the world?|url=http://espn.go.com/sports/soccer/news/_/id/5673975/success-germany-bundesliga|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=8 March 2015|date=21 October 2010}}</ref> This meant that clubs were run as [[not-for-profit organisations]], and private ownership was not allowed under any circumstances.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Müller|first1=Christian|title=Football Governance|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201011/cmselect/cmcumeds/writev/792/fg84.htm|website=www.parliament.uk|accessdate=8 March 2015|date=21 February 2011}}</ref> This changed following a ruling by the [[German Football Association]] (DFB) in October 1998, which allowed clubs to convert their football teams into public or private limited companies. However, the "50+1 rule" requires the parent club to own at least 50% plus one additional share of the football company, ensuring that the club's members still hold a majority of voting rights.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Honigstein|first1=Raphael|title=League crack down on lewd shirt numbers to concentrate on 50+1|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2009/feb/10/raphael-onigstein-bundesliga-blog-bayern-munich|website=The Guardian|date=10 February 2009|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
===Exceptions=== In cases where a person or company has substantially funded a club for a continuous period of 20 years, it is possible for that person or company to own a controlling stake in the club.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hesse|first1=Uli|title=Issues looming for Germany's footballing landscape|url=http://www.espnfc.com/german-bundesliga/10/blog/post/2219877/issues-looming-for-germanys-footballing-landscape|website=ESPN|accessdate=8 March 2015|date=30 December 2014}}</ref> This exception most notably applies to [[Bayer 04 Leverkusen]] (owned by pharmaceuticals company [[Bayer]]), and [[VfL Wolfsburg]] (owned by automobile manufacturer [[Volkswagen]]), and has more recently allowed [[SAP SE|SAP]] co-founder [[Dietmar Hopp]] to gain control of his former youth club of [[TSG 1899 Hoffenheim|1899 Hoffenheim]].
==Criticism== The rule has been criticised on a number of occasions. One of the rule's most vocal opponents is [[Hannover 96]] president [[Martin Kind]], who argued that the rule could be in breach of EU competition law.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Amies|first1=Nick|title=For better or worse, Bundesliga clubs to keep ownership rule|url=http://www.dw.de/for-better-or-worse-bundesliga-clubs-to-keep-ownership-rule/a-4909350|publisher=Deutsche Welle|accessdate=8 March 2015|date=19 November 2009}}</ref> In 2009, Hannover put forward a motion to change the 50+1 rule, but this was overwhelmingly rejected, with 32 out of 36 clubs voting against the proposal.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Conn|first1=David|title=Bundesliga votes to keep clubs owned by members|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/david-conn-inside-sport-blog/2009/nov/13/bundesligafootball-bayernmunich|website=The Guardian|accessdate=8 March 2015|date=13 November 2009}}</ref>
The effectiveness of the rule has also been brought into question following the rise of [[RB Leipzig]]. Although it is theoretically possible to become a voting member here, RB Leipzig reserves the right to reject any membership application without citing a reason. As a result, RB Leipzig has only a handful of members, most of whom are Red Bull GmbH employees. Critics have also noted that the annual membership fee is relatively expensive compared to other clubs.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Oltermann|first1=Philip|title=Why RB Leipzig are sending shockwaves through German football|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2014/mar/06/rb-leipzig-sending-shockwaves-through-german-football|website=The Guardian|accessdate=8 March 2015|date=6 March 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.bundesliga.de/de/dfl/statuten/ Statuten DFL - bundesliga.de - die offizielle Webseite der Bundesliga] {{de icon}}

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Abbotsford Centre | logo_image = AESC logo.jpg | image = | caption = | location = 33800 King Road
[[Abbotsford, British Columbia|Abbotsford]], [[British Columbia]]
V2S 8H8 | coordinates = {{coord|49.030665|-122.287145|display=it|type:landmark}} | broke_ground = September 24, 2007 | built = | opened = May 10, 2009 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Abbotsford, British Columbia|City of Abbotsford]] | operator = [[Comcast Spectacor|Global Spectrum]] | construction_cost = [[Canadian dollar|{{dollarsign|CAD}}]]66.2 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|CA|66200000|2009}}}} in {{Inflation-year|CA}} dollars{{inflation-fn|CA}}) | architect = PBK Architects | project_manager = MHPM Project Managers Inc. | structural engineer = Cochrane Engineering[http://www.journalofcommerce.com/article/id33017/gtcontracting City of Abbotsford, B.C. bundles projects to get them done] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120430095721/http://www.journalofcommerce.com/article/id33017/gtcontracting |date=April 30, 2012 }} | services engineer = | general_contractor = [[PCL Construction|PCL Constructors Westcoast Inc.]][http://www.pcl.com/Projects-that-Inspire/Pages/Abbotsford-Entertainment-Sports-Centre.aspx PCL: Abbotsford Entertainment & Sports Centre] | former_names = | tenants = [[Abbotsford Heat]] ([[American Hockey League|AHL]]) (2009–2014)
[[BC Angels]] ([[LFL Canada]]) (2012–2013)
[[Fraser Valley Bandits]] ([[Canadian Elite Basketball League|CEBL]]) (2019–) | seating_capacity = Hockey: 7,000
Basketball: 7,046
Concerts: 8,500 }} The '''Abbotsford Centre''' is a 7,000-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[Abbotsford, British Columbia|Abbotsford]], [[British Columbia]]. The arena was expected to cost $64.7-million.City of Abbotsford (March 29, 2007). ''[http://plana.abbotsford.ca/AssetFactory.aspx?did=5357 Plan A Financial Summary]''. Retrieved on April 11, 2007. Construction began on September 24, 2007.{{cite news |title=Abbotsford Gets Lowdown on Entertainment and Sports Centre|newspaper=[[Abbotsford Times]]|date=February 15, 2008}} From 2009 to 2014, it was the home of the [[Abbotsford Heat]] of the [[American Hockey League]].{{cite web|url=http://www.fraservalleyahl.com/2009-05-14-news.pdf |title=The HEAT is on for 2009-10 AHL season |publisher=Fraser Valley Sports & Entertainment Ltd. |date=May 14, 2009 |accessdate=May 14, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711023045/http://www.fraservalleyahl.com/2009-05-14-news.pdf |archivedate=July 11, 2011 }} ==History== On September 25, 2006, Abbotsford council voted unanimously to hold a [[referendum]] asking voters to borrow $85-million to fund three community projects, including a new entertainment and sports centre.City of Abbotsford (February 12, 2007). ''[http://plana.abbotsford.ca/AssetFactory.aspx?did=5022 Regular Update - Plan A: Week of February 12, 2007]''. Retrieved on April 7, 2007. The arena was approved by Abbotsford voters on November 25, 2006 with a 54.8% majority.{{cite web|title=Plan A |url=http://www.abbotsford.ca/PageFactory.aspx?PageID=681 |publisher=City of Abbotsford |accessdate=April 7, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928211502/http://www.abbotsford.ca/PageFactory.aspx?PageID=681 |archivedate=September 28, 2007 |deadurl=no |df= }} With the loss of the Heat, Abbotsford Centre announced it would start a recreational ice hockey league to help fill open dates left at the arena. Each team in the Abbotsford Centre Hockey League is to play 20 games per team during the 2014-15 hockey season.{{cite web|url=http://abbotsfordcentre.pointstreaksites.com/view/abbotsfordcentre/news-1570/news_163691 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-08-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140814064107/http://abbotsfordcentre.pointstreaksites.com/view/abbotsfordcentre/news-1570/news_163691 |archivedate=2014-08-14 |df= }} It is unknown if there will be paid admission for each game. On May 2, 2018, the [[Canadian Elite Basketball League]] announced that a professional basketball team called the [[Fraser Valley Bandits]] will be coming to the Abbotsford Centre in 2019, with the basketball season to be from May to August.[https://www.bclocalnews.com/sports/pro-basketball-coming-to-abbotsford/ CEBL to bring a Pro Basketball Team to the Abbotsford Centre] ==Arena amenities== The arena has a capacity of 7,000 seats for hockey with room for expansion to 8,500. There are 300 club seats, 15 boxes, 20 private suites, and 2 party suites.City of Abbotsford (March 29, 2007). ''[http://plana.abbotsford.ca/AssetFactory.aspx?did=5356 Award Construction Contract for Plan "A" Projects]''. Retrieved on April 11, 2007. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.abbotsfordcentre.ca/ Official website] {{Canadian Elite Basketball League}} {{LFL Venues}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Abbotsford Entertainment and Sports Centre}} [[Category:Abbotsford Heat]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Abbotsford, British Columbia]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in British Columbia]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Canada]] [[Category:Sports venues in British Columbia]] [[Category:Legends Football League venues]] [[Category:2009 establishments in British Columbia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2009]] {{canada-icehockey-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox football club | clubname = Al-Wahda SC
نادي الوحدة الرياضي | image = | fullname = Al-Wahda Sports Club | nickname = | founded = {{Start date and age|1970}} | ground = [[Sur Sports Complex]]
[[Sur, Oman|Sur]], [[Oman]] | capacity = 8,000 | chairman = | manager = | league = [[Omani League]] | season = [[2007–08 Omani League|2007–08]] | position = '''10th''' (Promotion/Relegation Play-off) | pattern_la1 = |pattern_b1 =_unknown|pattern_ra1 = | leftarm1 = |body1 =|rightarm1 =|shorts1 =|socks1 = | pattern_la2 = |pattern_b2 =_unknown|pattern_ra2 = | leftarm2 = |body2 =|rightarm2 =|shorts2 =|socks2 = }} '''Al-Wahda Sports Club''' ({{lang-ar|نادي الوحدة الرياضي}}) is an [[Football clubs of Oman|Omani sports club]] based in [[Sur, Oman|Sur]], [[Oman]].{{cite web | url = http://www.national-football-teams.com/club/16428/2013_1/Al_Wehda_Sur.html | title = Al-Wehda Sur | publisher = national-football-teams.com}} The club is currently playing in the [[First Division League]] of [[Oman Football Association]]. Their home ground is [[Sur Sports Complex]]. The stadium is government owned, but they also own their own personal stadium and sports equipment, as well as their own training facilities. ==Being a multisport club== Although being mainly known for their football, Al-Wahda SC like many other clubs in Oman, have not only football in their list, but also [[field hockey|hockey]], [[volleyball]], [[Team handball|handball]], [[basketball]], [[badminton]] and [[squash (sport)|squash]]. They also have a youth football team competing in the Omani Youth league. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/oman/al-wehda/10124/ Al-Wahda SC Profile at Soccerway.com] *[http://www.futbol24.com/team/Oman/Al-Wahda-Oman/ Al-Wahda SC Profile at Futbol24.com] *[http://www.goalzz.com/main.aspx?team=5839 Al-Wahda SC Profile at Goalzz.com] {{DEFAULTSORT:Al-Wahda Sports Club}} [[Category:Football clubs in Oman]] [[Category:Omani League]] [[Category:Sur, Oman]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1970]] [[Category:1970 establishments in Oman]] [[Category:Omani sport stubs]] [[Category:Asian football club stubs]] {{Oman-footyclub-stub}}

{{about|American football|association football|Austrian Football Bundesliga}} {{Infobox Sports league | title = Austrian Football League | current_season = | last_season = | upcoming_season = | logo = | pixels = 100px | caption = | Formerly = | sport = American football | founded = {{Start date and age|1984}} | fame = | motto = | inaugural = | teams = 8 | country = {{flagu|Austria}}
{{flagu|Slovenia}}
{{flagu|Slovakia}} | venue = | champion = [[Swarco Raiders Tirol]] | most_champs = [[Vienna Vikings]] (14) | qualification = | folded = | website = [http://www.afboe.at/ afboe.at] | singles = | ceo = | Director = | TV = | related_comps = | Founder = | footnotes = }} The '''Austrian Football League''' ('''AFL''') is the elite league of [[American football]] in [[Austria]]. The league was founded in 1984 and plays by the rules of the [[NCAA]]. ==History== The AFL is commonly considered as one of the best American football leagues in Europe, hence the [[European Football League|EFL]] was won seven times by AFL teams in the eight-year period from 2004 to 2011.{{cite web|title=Eurobowl.info|url=http://www.eurobowl.info/}} In 2010, eight teams participated in the league, with seven being from Austria and one, the [[Prague Panthers]] from the [[Czech Republic]]. In 2012, six teams participated in the league, with five being from Austria and one, the Prague Panthers from the Czech Republic. The regular season consists of ten games and starts in mid March and the playoffs continue through July. The final game is called the Austrian Bowl and was held for the first time in 1984 in [[Salzburg, Austria]]. ==Teams== [[File:2010-06-12 dra-vik snap.jpg|thumb|300px|"Blue River Bowl III": [[:de:Danube Dragons|Danube Dragons]] vs. [[Vienna Vikings|Vikings]] at [[:de:Dimmi-Arena|Rattenfängerstadion]] in [[Korneuburg]], 2010]] In 2018, the AFL consisted of: *[[Vienna Vikings]] *[[:de:Graz Giants|Graz Giants]] *[[Swarco Raiders Tirol]] *[[:de:Danube Dragons|Danube Dragons]] *[[Bratislava Monarchs]] *[[:de:AFC Rangers|AFC Rangers]] *[[Ljubljana Silverhawks]] *[[Steelsharks Traun]] ==Austrian Bowl== ===All games=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! {{Infobox organization | name = Beach Soccer Worldwide | native_name = | image = File:BSWW logo 2016.png | size = 160px | alt = | caption = | map = | msize = | malt = | mcaption = | abbreviation = BSWW | motto = | formation = 1992 (founding partners)
2001 (current status) | extinction = | type = [[List of international sport federations|International sport federation]] | status = | purpose = | headquarters = [[Barcelona]], [[Spain]] | coords = | region_served = Worldwide | membership = [[List of men's national association football teams|209 national associations]] of FIFA + unofficial | languages = English | leader_title = President | leader_name = Luis Felipe Tavares{{cite news|url=http://www.beachsoccer.com/news/dubai-makes-it-again |title= Dubai makes it again! |work= beachsoccer.com|date=7 November 2012 |accessdate=27 April 2016}} | leader_title2 = Vice-President | leader_name2 = Joan Cuscó{{cite news |url=http://www.octagon.com/who_we_are/leadership/joan_cusco |title=Joan Cuscó, President, Octagon Spain |work=octagon.com |accessdate=27 April 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160413131233/http://www.octagon.com/who_we_are/leadership/joan_cusco |archivedate=13 April 2016 |df= }} | leader_title3 = Deputy vice-president | leader_name3 = Gabino Renales{{cite news|url=http://www.beachsoccer.com/editorials/21 |title= Beach Soccer takes a new step forward in Estonia |work= beachsoccer.com |date=23 August 2015 |accessdate=27 April 2016}} | main_organ = | parent_organization = | affiliations = [[FIFA]],
[[International Olympic Committee]]{{cite news|url=http://www.eurolympic.org/images/baku-sports/Beach_Soccer.pdf |title=Beach Soccer Worldwide – Beach Soccer |work=eurolympic.org |date=April 2014 |accessdate=27 April 2016 |dead-url=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151023213358/http://www.eurolympic.org/images/baku-sports/Beach_Soccer.pdf |archivedate=October 23, 2015 }} | num_staff = <50{{cite news|url=https://www.linkedin.com/company/beach-soccer-worldwide |title= Keep up with Beach Soccer Worldwide |work= linkedin.com |accessdate=27 April 2016}} | num_volunteers = | budget = | website = {{URL|http://www.beachsoccer.com/}} | remarks = }} '''Beach Soccer Worldwide''' ('''BSWW''') is the organisation responsible for the founding and growth of [[association football]]'s derivative sport of [[beach soccer]]. The founding partners of BSWW codified the rules of beach soccer in 1992, with BSWW as it is known today having been officially founded in 2001 as a singular institution to develop the sport and organise international beach soccer competitions across the globe, primarily between national teams. The company is recognised as playing the biggest role in helping to establish the rules of beach soccer, to spread and evolve the sport around the world as cited by FIFA who took on governing body status of the sport from BSWW in 2005. Having established the sport's key regulations, FIFA acknowledged BSWW's framework, making their rules the official laws of beach soccer and now controls them and any modifications. Today, under the recognition of FIFA, BSWW continues to be main organisation that organises beach soccer tournaments and development (with FIFA's assistance) around the world, mainly in Europe, including the Euro Beach Soccer League, BSWW exhibition tour events and others, having involved over 110 national teams in the sport, as well as newly founded club competitions. Its founders also established the [[Beach Soccer World Championships]]; BSWW created a partnership with [[FIFA]], ''FIFA Beach Soccer S.L.'', in 2005 to manage the tournament as the newly named [[FIFA Beach Soccer World Cup]], the only major international beach soccer tournament that BSWW does not have a hand in organising but which is all the management of FIFA. Members of the organisation serve on FIFA's Beach Soccer Committee. ==History== {{see also|Beach Soccer#Rules}} ===Founding=== BSWW's routes are traced back to 1992 with the establishment of the official rules of the sport by Giancarlo Signorini, the founding partner of ''Beach Soccer Company (BSC)''.{{cite web|url=http://www.beachsoccer.com/history.htm |title=The History and Growth of Pro Beach Soccer (1992 to Present) |publisher=beachsoccer.com |date=2001 |accessdate=28 April 2016 |dead-url=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020215032512/http://www.beachsoccer.com/history.htm |archivedate=February 15, 2002 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.soccer-tournament-guide.com/Life-is-a-Beach.html|title=Life is a Beach|publisher=soccer-tournament-guide.com|accessdate=28 April 2016}} In 1992, Signorini staged a pilot event in [[Los Angeles]] in order to test out and perfect these rules which remain very similar today. In July 1993, with the aid of his own company, BSI, Signorini organised the first professional beach soccer event, held on [[Miami Beach]], [[Florida]]. A keen interest was taken by Brazilian sports marketing agency, Koch Tavares, who replicated the event in 1994 in [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Brazil]] and Viking Graham Sports Group, a [[Philadelphia]] based investment group, acquired BSI's rights to stage professional beach soccer events, forming a partnership with Signorini to create ''Beach Soccer Company''.{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Daily/Issues/1997/04/11/Leagues-Governing-Bodies/YOUNG-MEN-BY-THE-SEA-PRO-BEACH-SOCCER-TOUR-EXPANDS-SCHEDULE.aspx|title=YOUNG MEN BY THE SEA: PRO BEACH SOCCER TOUR EXPANDS SCHEDULE|publisher=sportsbusinessdaily.com|date=11 April 1997|accessdate=28 April 2016}} Koch Tavares and BSC went on to be the main two entities involved in promoting beach soccer for the rest of the 1990s, with the former responsible for organising the ''Beach Soccer World Championships'' beginning in 1995, and the latter establishing the ''[[Pro Beach Soccer Tour]]'' in 1996, a series of worldwide professional exhibition tournaments to promote the sport, and the ''[[Euro Beach Soccer League|European Pro Beach Soccer League]]'' in 1998, all contested between national teams as opposed to clubs. BSC relocated to [[Monaco]] in 1998 and again to Barcelona in 1999, renaming to become ''Pro Beach Soccer, S.L. (PBS)'' in 2000 to reflect the branding of their established events. In 2001, the entity of Koch Tavares responsible for beach soccer and PBS came together to create one single company in order to streamline development of the sport under one unifying company, as opposed to multiple parties involved trying to synchronise progress between one another, officially forming Beach Soccer Worldwide, opting to remain based in Barcelona.{{cite web|url=http://www.beachsoccer-dbsv.de/|title=BeachSoccer|publisher=beachsoccer-dbsv.de|accessdate=28 April 2016|language=German}} BSWW took on roles of organising all major competitions of the preceding companies including the [[Pro Beach Soccer Tour]] and [[Euro Beach Soccer League|European Pro Beach Soccer League]], whilst supervising the [[FIFA Beach Soccer World Cup|World Championships]] and the newly created America's League, all remaining focused on national teams. This was also done to make it easier to bring on board sponsors, coordinate media coverage and present the football alternative to FIFA under a clearly defined, all-encompassing, representative body for beach soccer. ===FIFA partnership=== [[Image:Challenge Cup Israel v Turkey 2.jpg|thumb|290px|right|A scene from a 2008 BSWW Tour event between [[Israel national beach soccer team|Israel]] and [[Turkey national beach soccer team|Turkey]]]] BSWW's attention immediately turned to FIFA. Beach Soccer Company had already ensured all tournaments from 2000 onwards were played under [[Association football culture#Fair Play|FIFA's fair play]] rules and delegates from both parties met multiple times to discuss for BSWW's rules of the sport and competitions to gain recognition and backing of football's governing body.{{cite web|url=http://www.beachsoccer.com/index2.asp?main=fifa.htm |title=FIFA |publisher=beachsoccer.com |date=2001 |accessdate=28 April 2016 |dead-url=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040605205650/http://www.beachsoccer.com/index2.asp?main=fifa.htm |archivedate=June 5, 2004 }} By 2002, FIFA had come to an agreement with BSWW to adopt the rules and regulations that had been established over the previous decade, with some minor changes to ensure FIFA's interest in key components of regular football were respected and acknowledging key major tournaments in the sport including the World Championships.{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/development/news/y=2002/m=2/news=attractive-sport-with-bright-future-81212.html |title=An Attractive Sport with a Bright Future|publisher=fifa.com|date=22 February 2002|accessdate=28 April 2016}} During this time, BSWW also brought on board major sponsors such as [[MasterCard]], [[McDonald's]] and [[Coca-Cola]] for certain time period.{{cite web|url=http://www.beachsoccer.com/corp_history_02.php?idn=9&seccion=3&action=open&id=3 |title=BSWW History |publisher=beachsoccer.com |date=2004 |accessdate=28 April 2016 |dead-url=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061025124334/http://www.beachsoccer.com/corp_history_02.php?idn=9&seccion=3&action=open&id=3 |archivedate=October 25, 2006 }} The involvement with FIFA was furthered in 2004 when ''FIFA Beach Soccer S.L.'' was established in agreement and partnership with BSWW, to take over responsibility of the World Championships, being beach soccer's primary tournament, to become an official FIFA competition.{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/about-fifa/news/y=2004/m=10/news=fifa-executive-committee-confirms-the-strategic-studies-committee-prop-94383.html|title=FIFA Executive Committee confirms the Strategic Studies Committee's proposals and adopts FIFA Code of Ethics|publisher=fifa.com|date=6 October 2004|accessdate=28 April 2016}} The newly named ''FIFA Beach Soccer World Cup'' would start in 2005, with BSWW staff acting as advisers. It was also agreed that FIFA would become the sport's governing body, taking over from BSWW.{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/media/news/y=2005/m=2/news=fifa-launches-first-ever-fifa-beach-soccer-world-cup-96141.html|title=FIFA launches first ever FIFA Beach Soccer World Cup|publisher=fifa.com|date=1 February 2005|accessdate=28 April 2016}} However at this time FIFA also recognised BSWW as the main entity behind past and more importantly continuing promotion and development of the sport elsewhere besides the new World Cup, and so BSWW retained the organisation responsibilities and control of other beach soccer championships like the EBSL, with FIFA only taking full control of the World Cup.{{cite web|url=http://www.beachsoccer.com/corp_thebsww.php?idn=8&seccion=3&action=open&id=2 |title=the bsww |publisher=beachsoccer.com |date=2004 |accessdate=28 April 2016 |dead-url=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061025123537/http://www.beachsoccer.com/corp_thebsww.php?idn=8&seccion=3&action=open&id=2 |archivedate=October 25, 2006 }} So much so that after the first successful World Cup in 2005, when FIFA established World Cup qualifying tournaments to promote the sport across all confederations to start in 2006, all responsibility was handed to BSWW to organise and execute such events, with FIFA only supervising.{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/documents/tournaments/BSWC2006/FIFA_beach_soccer_world_cup_2006_regulations_en.pdf |title=Regulations FIFA Beach Soccer World Cup Rio de Janeiro 2006 |publisher=fifa.com |date=November 2006 |accessdate=28 April 2016 |dead-url=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070107132659/http://www.fifa.com/documents/tournaments/BSWC2006/FIFA_beach_soccer_world_cup_2006_regulations_en.pdf |archivedate=January 7, 2007 }} ===Continued development=== [[File:Joan Cusco.jpg|thumb|290px|right|BSWW Vice-President and FIFA committee member Joan Cuscó]] [[File:FUTBOL PLAYA (17098874369).jpg|thumb|290px|right|A scene from the [[2015 CONMEBOL Beach Soccer Championship]] match between Brazil and Paraguay with the BSWW logo on hoarding visible in the background]] Since then, BSWW has continued to develop the sport worldwide, now aided greatly with FIFA's beach soccer training courses and refereeing.{{cite web|url=http://www.beachsoccer.com/news/beach-soccer-expansion-is-reaching-new-heights|title=Beach soccer expansion is reaching new heights|publisher=beachsoccer.com|date=19 February 2015|accessdate=28 April 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://beachsoccer.com/editorials/23|title=Development programs: Planning comes first|publisher=beachsoccer.com|date=4 April 2016|accessdate=28 April 2016}} The Euro Beach Soccer League (dropping the ''pro'' from the title in 2004 as it was no longer reflecting of the company name){{cite web|url=http://footballfriendsonline.com/2011/04/18/beach-soccer-a-developing-sport/|title=Beach Soccer … A Developing Sport|publisher=footballfriendsonline.com|date=18 April 2011|accessdate=28 April 2016}} has remained BSWW's main asset, gathering up to 27 nations to compete in recent editions compared to just 7 in the first event in 1998 in a summer-long event. The Pro Beach Soccer Tour has also been renamed to the BSWW Tour for the same reasons, continuing exhibition events to promote the sport as far wide and remote as [[Réunion]] and [[Cape Verde]] with around 10 tour events a year.{{cite web|url=http://beachsoccer.com/tournaments/4|title=BSWW Tour|publisher=beachsoccer.com|accessdate=28 April 2016}} BSWW has continued organising the World Cup qualifiers, as well as establishing new regular international competitions such as the [[Beach Soccer Intercontinental Cup|Intercontinental Cup]] (similar to the [[FIFA Confederations Cup]]) since 2011 and generating more interest from big sponsors like [[Samsung]]{{cite web|url=http://www.beachsoccer.com/news/samsung-partners-with-intercontinental-cup-2011|title=Samsung partners with Intercontinental Cup 2011|publisher=beachsoccer.com|date=2 November 2011|accessdate=28 April 2016}} and [[Huawei]].{{cite web|url=http://beachsoccer.com/news/huawei-official-sponsor-of-the-intercontinental-cup|title=Huawei, official sponsor of the Intercontinental Cup|publisher=beachsoccer.com|date=27 October 2017|accessdate=6 November 2017}} BSWW representatives, in partnership with FIFA, have liaised with the [[International Olympic Committee]] a number of times, with Olympic-affiliated events such as the [[Asian Beach Games]] integrating beach soccer from 2008 onward, the [[South American Beach Games]] from 2009 and the [[European Games]] starting from 2015. The ultimate aim is to have beach soccer a sport in the [[summer Olympics]].{{cite web|url=http://sport360.com/video/football/38525/video-beach-soccer-would-sell-out-rio-olympics|title=VIDEO: Beach Soccer would ‘sell out’ Rio Olympics|publisher=Sport360|date=23 June 2015|accessdate=28 April 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.beachsoccer.com/news/hickey-beach-soccer-deserves-to-be-in-the-olympics|title=Hickey: "Beach Soccer deserves to be in the Olympics"|publisher=beachsoccer.com|date=27 June 2015|accessdate=28 April 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.baku2015.com/news/article/olympic-goal-sight-beach-soccer-seizes-chance-shine-39360.html|title=European Games are Beach Soccer's opportunity to show off to the world|publisher=baku2015.com|date=12 June 2015|accessdate=28 April 2016}} But despite a campaign for inclusion in the [[Rio 2016]] and [[Tokyo 2020|Tokyo 2020 Olympics.]], the sport was ultimately not included and so lobbying in cooperation with FIFA continues,{{cite web|url=http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/722484.shtml|title=IOC rules out including beach soccer, futsal at Rio Games|publisher=globaltimes.cn|date=22 July 2012|accessdate=28 April 2016}} to ultimately fulfil the goal of making beach soccer an Olympic sport. In 2017, BSWW secured beach soccer as a sport at the inaugural Olympic-affiliated [[2019 World Beach Games|World Beach Games in 2019]] and hope to use its inclusion as a springboard for future absorption into the Summer Olympics.{{cite web|url=http://beachsoccer.com/news/fifa-beach-soccer-workshop-live-updates|title=FIFA Beach Soccer Workshop held in Dubai|publisher=globaltimes.cn|date=3 November 2017|accessdate=6 November 2017}} More recently, a greater involvement from certain confederations in organising World Cup qualifying championships has eased the full involvement of BSWW,{{cite web|url=http://www.beachsoccer.com/news/bsww-and-afc-sign-long-term-agreement|title=BSWW and AFC sign long term agreement|publisher=beachsoccer.com|date=10 May 2014|accessdate=6 November 2017}} allowing the federation to promote the club side of the game more, establishing the [[Mundialito de Clubs]] (Club World Cup) in 2011{{cite web|url=http://www.beachsoccer.com/news/the-clubs-competition-comes-true-the-new-reality-of-beach-soccer-is-here|title=The Clubs competition comes true: the new reality of Beach Soccer is here|publisher=beachsoccer.com|date=11 January 2011|accessdate=28 April 2016}} and the [[Euro Winners Cup]] (similar to the [[UEFA Champions League]]) in 2013.{{cite web|url=http://beachsoccer.com/news/san-benedetto-start-engines|title=San Benedetto start engines|publisher=beachsoccer.com|date=7 March 2013|accessdate=28 April 2016}} Development of the women's game has also become a target for BSWW, with the first official game between Switzerland and Germany in 2009,{{cite web|url=http://theroonba.com/beachwom09.htm|title=INTERNATIONAL BEACH SOCCER RESULTS - 2009 (WOMEN)|publisher=theroonba.com|accessdate=28 April 2016}} promoting further international exhibition tournaments and friendlies involving nations such as England, Italy and the Czech Republic, with the Euro Winners Cup having a 16-club women's version for the first time in 2016{{cite web|url=http://www.beachsoccer.com/news/the-biggest-euro-winners-cup-ever|title=The biggest Euro Winners Cup ever!|publisher=beachsoccer.com|date=18 February 2016}} and the first Women's [[Euro Beach Soccer Cup]] also taking place in 2016. BSWW has organised and delivered over 200 international events in more than 50 countries worldwide, involving over 110 nations from all confederations, assembling an audience of over 250 million households in 180 countries.{{cite web|url=http://beachsoccer.com/corporate|title=BEACH SOCCER CORPORATE|publisher=beachsoccer.com |accessdate=28 April 2016}} Vice-president Joan Cuscó continues to serve on FIFA's Beach Soccer committee as BSWW's representative.{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/about-fifa/committees/committee=1934062/index.html|title=Beach Soccer Committee|publisher=fifa.com |accessdate=28 April 2016}} In 2017, BSWW and FIFA agreed to extend their partnership until at least 2024.{{cite web|url=http://beachsoccerrussia.ru/info/item/8047?type=2|title=Хорошие новости и текущие трудности. Итоги воркшопа BSWW в Дубае|publisher=beachsoccerrussia.ru |date=4 November 2017}} ;Logo timeline {{center| File:BSWW logo 2001-08.png|'''2001–2008 File:Logo of Beach Soccer Worldwide.png|'''2009–2016 File:BSWW logo 2016.png |'''2016–present }} ==Rankings== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%; float: right; margin-left: 1em" |- |colspan=5 align="center"|'''Top 5 Rankings as of October 2018''' |- !Rank||Change||Team||Points||Confederation |- |align="right"|1 | align="center"|{{steady}} || {{beachsoccer|BRA}} || align="right"|3880|| align="center" style="background:#c0f8c0;"|[[CONMEBOL]] |- |align="right"|2 | align="center"|{{steady}} || {{beachsoccer|POR}} || align="right"|2601|| align="center" style="background:#d9edf4;"|[[UEFA]] |- |align="right"|3 | align="center"|{{steady}} || {{beachsoccer|IRN}} || align="right"|2411|| align="center" style="background:#FF66FF;"|[[Asian Football Confederation|AFC]] |- |align="right"|4 | align="center"|{{steady}} || {{beachsoccer|ITA}} || align="right"|1978|| align="center" style="background:#d9edf4;"|[[UEFA]] |- |align="right"|5 | align="center"|{{steady}} || {{beachsoccer|RUS}} || align="right"|1950|| align="center" style="background:#d9edf4;"|[[UEFA]] |} {{main article|BSWW World Rankings}} BSWW established a ranking system for European teams in the mid-2000s as the majority of tournaments are held in Europe and it is the most active continent for national teams. Hence the ranking was used for seeding in competitions like the EBSL.{{cite web|url=https://www.plazovakopana.cz/clanky/reprezentace/bsww-aktualni-zebricek-evropskych-zemi-2010.html |title=BSWW - aktuální žebříček evropských zemí 2010 |publisher=plazovakopana.cz |date=2010 |accessdate=27 April 2016 |language=Czech |dead-url=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120317185020/https://www.plazovakopana.cz/clanky/reprezentace/bsww-aktualni-zebricek-evropskych-zemi-2010.html |archivedate=March 17, 2012 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.beachsoccer.com/news/27-teams-in-4-groups-will-take-part-in-the-european-qualifier|title=27 teams in 4 groups will take part in the European Qualifier|publisher=beachsoccer.com|date=23 June 2010|accessdate=27 April 2016}} However, in 2014, BSWW created the first world ranking table based on a similar system to [[FIFA World Ranking|FIFA's world ranking]] for association football national teams.{{cite web|url=http://www.beachsoccer.com/ranking/overall|title=BSWW Beach Soccer rankings As per December 2015|publisher=beachsoccer.com|accessdate=28 April 2016}} ==Sponsors== '''Global Partners:''' * [[Prozis]] * The Islands of the Bahamas * [[Mycujoo]] '''Suppliers:''' * arena group * Akertime Sports Solutions == BSWW structured tournaments == {| class=wikitable style="font-size:90%; float: right; margin-left: 1em" |- !colspan="2"|Current Champions |- | '''FIFA Beach Soccer World Cup''' | {{beachsoccer|BRA}} ([[2017 FIFA Beach Soccer World Cup|2017]]) |- ! colspan=2 background:#fff;" | |- | '''AFC Beach Soccer Championship''' | {{beachsoccer|IRI}} ([[2017 AFC Beach Soccer Championship|2017]]) |- | '''Africa Beach Soccer Cup of Nations''' | {{beachsoccer|SEN}} ([[2016 CAF Beach Soccer Championship|2016]]) |- | '''CONCACAF Beach Soccer Championship''' | {{beachsoccer|PAN}} ([[2017 CONCACAF Beach Soccer Championship|2017]]) |- | '''CONMEBOL Beach Soccer Championship''' | {{beachsoccer|BRA}} ([[2017 CONMEBOL Beach Soccer Championship|2017]]) |- | '''OFC Beach Soccer Championship''' | {{beachsoccer|SOL}} ([[2013 OFC Beach Soccer Championship|2013]]) |- ! colspan=2 background:#fff;" | |- | '''FIFA Beach Soccer World Cup qualifiers (UEFA)''' | {{beachsoccer|POL}} ([[2017 FIFA Beach Soccer World Cup qualification (UEFA)|2017]]) |- | '''Euro Beach Soccer League''' | {{beachsoccer|ITA}} ([[2018 Euro Beach Soccer League|2018]]) |- | '''Euro Beach Soccer Cup''' | {{beachsoccer|POR}} ([[2016 Euro Beach Soccer Cup|2016]]) |- | '''Intercontinental Cup''' | {{beachsoccer|IRN}} ([[2018 Beach Soccer Intercontinental Cup|2018]]) |- | '''Mundialito''' | {{beachsoccer|POR}} ([[2018 BSWW Mundialito|2018]]) |- | '''Mundialito de Clubes''' (club) | {{flagicon|RUS}} [[BSC Lokomotiv Moscow|Lokomotiv Moscow]] ([[2017 Mundialito de Clubes|2017]]) |- | '''Euro Winners Cup''' (club) | {{flagicon|POR}} [[S.C. Braga (beach soccer)|S.C. Braga]] ([[2018 Euro Winners Cup|2018]]) |- ! colspan=2 background:#fff;" | |- | '''Women's Euro Beach Soccer Cup''' | {{beachsoccerwomen|RUS}} ([[2018 Women's Euro Beach Soccer Cup|2018]]) |- | '''Women's Euro Winners Cup''' (club) | {{flagicon|RUS}} WFC Zvezda ([[2018 Women's Euro Winners Cup|2018]]) |- ! colspan=2 background:#fff;" | |- | '''Asian Beach Games''' | {{beachsoccer|JPN}} ([[Beach soccer at the 2016 Asian Beach Games|2016]]) |- | '''European Games''' | {{beachsoccer|RUS}} ([[Beach soccer at the 2015 European Games|2015]]) |- | '''Mediterranean Beach Games''' | {{beachsoccer|ITA}} ([[Beach soccer at the 2015 Mediterranean Beach Games|2015]]) |- | '''South American Beach Games''' | {{beachsoccer|BRA}} ([[2014 South American Beach Games|2014]]) |} BSWW organises and has an input in many different competitions; the following are regular events that are ongoing:{{cite web|url=https://issuu.com/remigaichbsww/docs/bsww_overview_2016-17_caa82681e9d6aa|title=BSWW overview 2016-17 |publisher=Beach Soccer Worldwide|date=16 January 2016|accessdate=6 November 2017}} '''Advisory role:''' * [[FIFA Beach Soccer World Cup]] '''Considerable input, with involvement from confederations, under the supervision of FIFA:''' * [[AFC Beach Soccer Championship]] * [[Africa Beach Soccer Cup of Nations]] * [[CONCACAF Beach Soccer Championship]] * [[CONMEBOL Beach Soccer Championship]] * [[OFC Beach Soccer Championship]] '''Full input:''' * [[FIFA Beach Soccer World Cup qualification (UEFA)|FIFA Beach Soccer World Cup qualifiers (UEFA)]] * [[Euro Beach Soccer League]] * [[Euro Beach Soccer Cup]] * [[Beach Soccer Intercontinental Cup|Intercontinental Cup]] * [[BSWW Mundialito|Mundialito]] * Multiple [[Pro Beach Soccer Tour|BSWW Tour]] exhibition tournaments per year * [[Mundialito de Clubes]] (club) * [[Euro Winners Cup]] (club) * [[Euro Beach Soccer Cup#Women's Event|Women's Euro Beach Soccer Cup]] * [[Women's Euro Winners Cup]] (club) '''Affiliation only:''' * [[World Beach Games]] * [[European Games]] * [[Asian Beach Games]] * [[Mediterranean Beach Games]] * [[South American Beach Games]] ==Stars awards== {| class=wikitable style="font-size:90%; float: right; margin-left: 1em" |- !colspan="2"|2018 individual award winners |- | '''Best player''' | {{flagicon|ESP}} Llorenç Gomez |- | '''Best goalkeeper''' | {{flagicon|POR}} [[Elinton Andrade]] |- | '''Best coach''' | {{flagicon|BRA}} Gilberto Costa |- | '''Rising star''' | {{flagicon|IRN}} Mohammad Moradi |- | '''Best goal''' | {{flagicon|ESP}} Eduard Suarez |- | '''Best women's player''' | {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Marina Fedorova]] |} {{main|Beach Soccer Stars}} It has been standard practice for BSWW to award prizes to the top scorer, [[MVP]] and best goalkeeper at the conclusion every event of their organisation. However, in 2014, BSWW took this concept of awards to a new level, establishing beach soccer's first annual end of season [[awards ceremony]], taking place during November in [[Dubai]].{{cite web|url=http://beachsoccer.com/news/stars-shine-bright-in-dubai |title=Stars shine bright in Dubai |publisher=beachsoccer.com |date=4 November 2014 |accessdate=7 November 2017 }} The ceremony, a gala event attended by many of the world's leading figures in the sport, celebrates the achievements of top performers worldwide over the course of the season{{cite web|url=http://www.beachsoccer.com/events/beach-soccer-stars-2016 |title=Beach Soccer Stars 2016 |publisher=beachsoccer.com |accessdate=7 November 2017}} and has been compared to [[The Best FIFA Football Awards|FIFA's The Best]] awards and the [[Ballon D'or]] in [[association football]],{{cite web|url=http://www.littlehamptongazette.co.uk/sport/football/kempson-scoops-women-s-beach-soccer-ballon-d-or-1-8232745 |title=Kempson scoops women's beach soccer 'Ballon d'Or' |publisher=Littlehampton Gazette |date=7 November 2017 |accessdate=11 November 2017}} in both importance, grandeur and equivalence for the those involved in beach soccer. Some of the many prizes awarded on the night include best player of the year, best coach of the year, best goal and best team.{{cite web|url=http://beachsoccer.com/events/beach-soccer-stars-2014 |title=Beach Soccer Stars 2014 |publisher=beachsoccer.com |accessdate=7 November 2017 }} ==Foundation== Beach Soccer Worldwide extends its commitment beyond purely sport development. In 2009, the Beach Soccer Foundation was created by BSWW to tackle three main issues surrounding the sport:{{cite web|url=http://beachsoccer.com/foundation|title=The Beach Soccer Foundation|publisher=beachsoccer.com |accessdate=28 April 2016}} * Environmental protection through awareness and recycling * The development of children and young people through sport * Awareness and prevention of [[skin cancer]] ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20160428180833/http://www.beachsoccer.com/ Official website], beachsoccer.com * [https://www.facebook.com/BeachSoccerWorldwide/ Beach Soccer Worldwide] on Facebook * [https://twitter.com/BeachSoccer_WW Beach Soccer Worldwide] on Twitter * [https://www.fifa.com/beachsoccerworldcup/ FIFA Beach Soccer] ==References== {{reflist|3}} {{International Beach Soccer}} [[Category:Beach soccer|Worldwide]] [[Category:International sports organizations]] [[Category:Organisations based in Barcelona]] [[Category:Sports organisations established in 2001]]

{{coord|39.663099|-75.748021|display=title}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Bob Hannah Stadium | image = | location = [[Newark, Delaware]]| broke_ground = | opened = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[University of Delaware]]| operator = | surface = Artificial Turf | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = Delaware Diamond | tenants = [[University of Delaware]] | seating_capacity = 1,300 | dimensions = Left Field - 320 feet
Center Field - 400 feet
Right Field - 330 feet

'''Fence Height'''

Left and Right Fields - 8 feet
Center Field - 8 feet}} '''Bob Hannah Stadium''' is a [[baseball]] stadium located at the [[University of Delaware]] in [[Newark, Delaware]]. It plays host to the [[Delaware Fightin' Blue Hens baseball]] team. The stadium's namesake, Bob Hannah, retired as head coach in 2000. The stadium seats 1,300 people for baseball. Features of the stadium include an enclosed press box, an outdoor batting cage, and banners on the outfield fence signifying Delaware's numerous conference titles and [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] appearances. The stadium underwent extensive renovations in 2014 that replaced the grass field with an artificial turf playing surface It also added heated dugouts, new stadium fencing and backstop area, a three tunnel batting cage, a new scoreboard, and improved bullpens. The field dimensions are 330' down the right field line, 320' down the left field line, and 400' to center field.{{cite web |url=http://www.bluehens.com/ViewArticle.dbml?&DB_OEM_ID=29100&ATCLID=209248401 |title=Bob Hannah Stadium |publisher=Delaware Blue Hens |access-date=June 18, 2017}} ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.bluehens.com/SportSelect.dbml?SPID=110413&SPSID=670286&DB_OEM_ID=29100 Delaware Blue Hens Baseball] {{University of Delaware}} {{Colonial Athletic Association baseball venue navbox}} {{Delaware NCAA Division I college baseball venue navbox}} [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Delaware]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Newark, Delaware]] [[Category:Delaware Fightin' Blue Hens baseball]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2000]] [[Category:2000 establishments in Delaware]] {{Delaware-baseball-venue-stub}}

{{refimprove|date=January 2008}} [[File:Guildford Flames At Milton Keynes Lightning.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Breakaway during a game between the [[Guildford Flames]] and the [[Milton Keynes Lightning]] ]] A '''breakaway''' is a situation in [[ice hockey]] in which a player with the [[Hockey puck|puck]] has no [[Defenceman (ice hockey)|defending players]], except for the [[goaltender]], between themselves and the opposing [[goal (hockey)|goal]], leaving them free to [[Ice skating|skate]] in and [[Shot (ice hockey)|shoot]] at will (before the out-of-position defenders can catch them). A breakaway is considered a lapse on the part of the defending team. If a player's progress is illegally impeded by an opposing player or if the goalie throws their stick at the oncoming player, the breakaway player is awarded a [[penalty shot (ice hockey)|penalty shot]]. If a player faces an empty net (i.e. the opposing team has pulled their goalie) and is illegally impeded by an opposing player, they are [[Awarded goal (ice hockey)|automatically awarded a goal]] for their team instead of taking a penalty shot.
==Defense against a breakaway==
*One theory about the best way for the goalie to react to a breakaway is called the "Y" theory. In this theory the goalie comes out to somewhere between halfway between the faceoff circle hashes and the crease or up to the hashes. From there the goalie lines up to the puck and skates backwards, following the puck. Based on the player's actions, the goalie can then drop and take the shot. If the player goes diagonally with the puck, the goalie splits off from going straight back and then goes diagonal either way. The "Y" comes from the going straight back and then the diagonal movement. That forms a "Y" representing how a goalie can potentially play that breakaway. *Another way the goalie can respond is to follow the blade of the stick. If it is more towards one side or the other, the goalie can usually anticipate where the shot is going to hit. *Yet another way is that if the shot is going to be high (can be determined if the stick blade is upright on the ice 90 degrees), the goalie can move up to cut off the angle on the player, and go down right before the shot is taken. This way, there is more of a chance that the puck will not go over the goalie into the net. *A goalie can go up to the player, dive down sideways, and collide with the player, forcing them to chip the puck over the goalie, or deke. Though this strategy for goalies can be risky, it can usually work, considering that usually the player's head is down looking at the puck, allowing the goalie to surprise the player. This term is collectively known as the "two-pad stack" or the "Hextall" because [[Ron Hextall]] was famous for diving and stacking the pads to take out opposing players' legs.[http://www.nhl.com/video/app?page=GameHighlights&service=page&gid=503&gtid=2&season=20062007&media=/20062007/02/0503/IH_NHL_2006_2007_503_2_700K_continuous.wmv (See at 1:25)]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} This is not recommended though at youth hockey levels as it can be very dangerous. *Until the mid-2010s, a way to avoid a particularly threatening breakaway (multiple skaters with no defenders approaching the net) would be to deliberately [[moving the goalposts|move the goalposts]] to stop play; although it was illegal, the resulting [[penalty shot]] would be contested with only one player (and be subject to the restrictions therein, such as continuously moving forward), reducing the chances of being scored upon. Most leagues began increasing the severity of the penalty on this tactic after goaltender [[David Leggio]] exploited it twice; in North America, such a move will result in the goaltender being ejected from the game, while in Germany, the [[Awarded goal (ice hockey)|goal is automatically awarded]].
==See also== *[[Goaltender]] *[[Overtime (ice hockey)]] *[[Penalty shot (ice hockey)]]
==References== * {{cite book |first=Andrew |last=Podnieks |title=The Complete Hockey Dictionary |publisher=Fenn Publishing |year=2007 |isbn=978-1-55168-309-6 |ref=harv}}
