[[Don Steele]]
[[Mary Woronov]] | music = [[Paul Chihara]] | cinematography = [[Tak Fujimoto]] | editing = [[Tina Hirsch]] | distributor = [[New World Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|1975|4|27}} | runtime = 80 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $300,000–$530,0009 Directors Rising From the Trashes: Nine Directors Rising From the Trashes 9 Directors Rising From the Trashes 9 Directors Rising From the Trashes From the Trashes From the Trashes From the Trashes Thomas, Kevin. Los Angeles Times (1923-Current File) [Los Angeles, Calif] 21 Dec 1975: m1.{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1975/0DR2K.php |title= Death Race 2000 - The Numbers|publisher=The Numbers |accessdate=2011-07-24}}Christopher T Koetting, ''Mind Warp!: The Fantastic True Story of Roger Corman's New World Pictures'', Hemlock Books. 2009 p 80-83 | gross = $5 million–$8 million }} '''''Death Race 2000''''' is a 1975 American [[action film]] directed by [[Paul Bartel]], and starring [[David Carradine]], [[Simone Griffeth]] and [[Sylvester Stallone]]. The film takes place in a [[dystopia]]n [[United States|American]] society in the year 2000, where the murderous Transcontinental Road Race has become a form of national entertainment. The [[screenplay]] is based on the [[short story]] "The Racer" by [[Ib Melchior]].Bosnan, John & Nichols, Peter "Death Race 2000" in Clute, John & Nichols, Peter eds. (1998) ''[[The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction]]'' (2nd edition) Orbit ==Plot== After the "World Crash of '79", massive civil unrest and economic ruin occurs. The United States government restructured into a totalitarian regime under martial law. To pacify the population, the government has organized the Transcontinental Road Race, where a group of drivers race across the country in their high-powered cars, infamous for violence, gore, and innocent pedestrians being struck for bonus points. In the year 2000, the five drivers in the 20th annual race, who all adhere to [[professional wrestling]]-style personas and drive appropriately themed cars, include ''[[Frankenstein (Death Race)|Frankenstein]]'', the mysterious black-garbed champion and national hero; ''Machine Gun Joe'', a Chicago tough-guy gangster; ''Calamity Jane'', a cowgirl; ''Matilda the Hun'', a neo-Nazi; and ''Nero the Hero'', a Roman gladiator. Each drives with a navigator of the opposite sex, who also implicitly functions as a love interest. The race is covered on national TV by a news team headed by the boisterous and comical Junior Bruce, seductive matron Grace Pander, and laconic commentator Harold (a parody of [[Howard Cosell]]). The game has sadistic rules, where killing babies and physically challenged people will give the player extra points. Machine Gun Joe is the main opposition to Frankenstein. A resistance group led by Thomasina Paine, a descendant of 1770s American Revolutionary [[Thomas Paine]], plans to rebel against Mr. President's regime by sabotaging the race, killing most of the drivers, and taking Frankenstein hostage as leverage against the President. The group is assisted by Paine's great-granddaughter Annie, Frankenstein's latest navigator. She plans to lure him into an ambush to be replaced by a double. Despite a pirated national broadcast made by Ms. Paine herself, the resistance's disruption of the race is covered up by the government and instead blamed on the [[France|French]], who are also blamed for ruining the country's economy and telephone system. At first, the Resistance's plan works. Nero is killed when he runs over a booby-trapped doll planted by the Resistance, which he mistakes for a real baby and proceeds to run it over to gain points. Matilda drives off a cliff while following a fake detour set up by the Resistance. Calamity Jane, who witnessed Matilda's death, inadvertently drives over a land mine trying to leave the area. This leaves only Frankenstein and Machine Gun Joe in the race. As Frankenstein nonchalantly survives every attempt made on his life during the race, Annie comes to discover that the Frankenstein she knows is anything but a willing government stooge, nor is he the original man. The current Frankenstein is, in fact, one of a number of random wards of the state trained exclusively to race in the identity. "When one is used up, they bring in another", he tells Annie. The current Frankenstein also reveals that he has his own plans: when he wins the race and shakes hands with Mr. President, he will detonate a grenade which has been implanted in his prosthetic right hand (he calls it his "hand grenade"), which he has kept concealed by keeping his glove on at all times (even while undressed). His plan goes awry, however, when Machine Gun Joe attacks and Annie kills him using Frankenstein's "hand" grenade. Having successfully outmaneuvered both the rival drivers and the Resistance, Frankenstein is declared the winner, although he is wounded and unable to carry out his original grenade attack plan. Annie instead dons Frankenstein's disguise and plans to stab Mr. President while standing in for him on the podium. As the president congratulates "Frankenstein" for his victory, in the process declaring war on the [[France|French]] and appointing Frankenstein leader of the war, Annie is mistakenly shot and wounded by her own grandmother, who is desperate for revenge against Frankenstein for having supposedly killed her during the race (he had actually just drugged her). The real Frankenstein takes advantage of the confusion and rams the President's stage with his car, finally fulfilling his lifelong desire to kill him. In the [[epilogue]], Annie and Frankenstein marry. Frankenstein, now President, abolishes the race and plans to rebuild the country. However, Junior Bruce starts to protest against it. When unable to find a moral reason to continue the race and desperate to have the race perpetuate, he starts shouting that it is a way of life, to keep America satisfied, to entertain and give the people what they want. Frankenstein, annoyed, runs him over with his car and drives off with Annie to the cheers and applause of the crowd. ==Cast== * [[David Carradine]] as [[Frankenstein (Death Race)|Frankenstein]] * [[Simone Griffeth]] as Annie Smith * [[Sylvester Stallone]] as Joe "Machine Gun" Viterbo * Sandy McCallum as "Mr. President" * [[Louisa Moritz]] as Myra * [[Don Steele]] as Junior Bruce * [[Mary Woronov]] as "Calamity" Jane Kelly * [[Roberta Collins]] as Matilda the Hun * [[Fred Grandy]] as "Herman the German" Boch * [[Martin Kove]] as Ray "Nero the Hero" Lonagan * [[Joyce Jameson]] as Grace Pander * Carle Bensen as Harold * Leslie McRay as Cleopatra * Harriet Medin as Thomasina Paine * Jan Worth as young reporter ==Production== [[Roger Corman]] wanted to make a futuristic action sports film to take advantage of the advance publicity of ''[[Rollerball (1975 film)|Rollerball]]'' (1975). He optioned a short story by [[Ib Melchior]] and hired [[Robert Thom (writer)|Robert Thom]] to adapt it. Director [[Paul Bartel]] felt this was unshootable, so [[Charles B. Griffith]] rewrote it. Corman wanted [[Peter Fonda]] to play the lead, but he was unavailable, so [[David Carradine]] was cast instead. Carradine was paid 10% of the film's gross — he and [[Ron Howard]] were the only stars of Roger Corman Productions to ever get a percentage of the gross. Bartel later recalled "We had terrible script problems; David had to finish his 'Kung Fu' series before starting and we had bad weather. We all worked under terrible pressure. Roger and I had an essential disagreement over comedy. He took out a lot of the comedy scenes. He may have been right and was probably more objective." Bartel later said, "Most of my guilty pleasures in this film were ripped out by the roots by Roger Corman before the film ever saw the light of day and substituted with crushed heads and blood squibs. Nevertheless, there is a joke about the French wrecking our economy and telephone system that I still find amusing. And I am pleased by the scene introducing the Girl Fan (played very effectively by my sister Wendy) who is to sacrifice herself beneath the wheels of David Carradine's race car and wants to meet him so that the gesture will have "meaning"."{{cite magazine|title=Paul Bartel's Guilty Pleasures|last=Bartel|first=Paul|magazine=Film Comment|edition=18.5|date=September–October 1982|pages= 60–62}} ==Reception== ===Box office=== According to ''Variety'' the film earned $4.8 million in rentals in the United States."All-time Film Rental Champs", ''Variety'', 7 January 1976 p 48 ===Critical=== Contemporary reviews were mixed. [[Lawrence Van Gelder]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' wrote that the film had "nothing to say beyond the superficial about government or rebellion. And in the absence of such a statement, it becomes what it seems to have mocked—a spectacle glorifying the car as an instrument of violence."{{cite journal |last=Van Gelder |first=Lawrence |authorlink=Lawrence Van Gelder |date=June 6, 1975 |title=The Screen: 'Death Race 2000' Is Short on Satire |url= |journal=[[The New York Times]] |page=17 }} ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' called the film "cartoonish but effective entertainment, with some good action sequences and plenty of black humor."{{cite journal |date=May 7, 1975 |title=Film Reviews: Death Race 2000 |url= |journal=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |page=48 }} Richard Combs of ''[[The Monthly Film Bulletin]]'' wrote that the comic conceits were "too shaky to hold the movie together and tend to self-destruct some distance short of any pop allegory for America."{{cite journal |last=Combs |first=Richard |date=February 1976 |title=Death Race 2000 |url= |journal=[[The Monthly Film Bulletin]] |volume=43 |issue=505 |page=27 }} [[Gene Siskel]] of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' gave the film one star out of four and wrote that it "may be the goofiest and sleaziest film I've seen in the last five years." [[Gene Siskel|Siskel, Gene]] (June 22, 1975). "Dismal duo for a drive-in double bill". ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''. Section 3, p. 5. [[Tom Shales]] of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' praised the film as "one of the zippier little B pictures of the year," adding that "it is designed primarily as a spectacle of kinetic titillation, and on that level, it's a foregone smash hit."{{cite journal |last=Shales |first=Tom |authorlink=Tom Shales |date=June 11, 1975 |title='Death Race 2000': Smashing And Ruthless Exploitation |url= |journal=[[The Washington Post]] |page=B6 }} [[Kevin Thomas (film critic)|Kevin Thomas]] of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' was also positive, calling it "a fine little action picture with big ideas" and finding Carradine "terrific" in his role.[[Kevin Thomas (film critic)|Thomas, Kevin]] (May 2, 1975). "Barbarism in Big Brother Era". ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''. Part IV, p. 21. [[Roger Ebert]] gave the film zero stars in his review, deriding its violence and lamenting its appeal to small children.{{cite news|url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19750427/REVIEWS/808259998/1023 |title=Roger Ebert's review |publisher=Rogerebert.suntimes.com |accessdate=2014-05-27 |date=1975-04-27}} However, during a review of ''[[The Fast and the Furious (2001 film)|The Fast and the Furious]]'' on ''[[At the Movies (1986 TV program)|Ebert & Roeper and the Movies]]'', Ebert named ''Death Race 2000'' as part of a "great tradition of summer drive-in movies" that embrace a "summer exploitation mentality in a clever way".{{cite news|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IJL5RJPLkKY |title=Ebert & Roeper: The Fast and the Furious (Year 2001)|publisher=YouTube |accessdate=2017-07-31 |date=2010-03-07}} Nevertheless, Ebert would go on to defend his original rating of zero stars in subsequent posts on his Movie Answers Man blog.{{cite news|url=http://www.rogerebert.com/answer-man/death-be-not-so-good-still |title='Death' Be Not So Good. Still.|publisher=RogerEbert.com |accessdate=2017-07-31 |date=2008-08-28}}{{cite news|url=http://www.rogerebert.com/answer-man/those-coen-boys-what-kidders |title=Those Coen Boys, What Kidders.|publisher=RogerEbert.com |accessdate=2017-07-31 |date=2008-09-11}} The film has garnered critical acclaim over the years, having a score of 83% on the film critics site, [[Rotten Tomatoes]] based on 35 reviews, with an average rating of 6.7/10, deeming it "fresh". The sites' critical consensus states, "''Death Race 2000'' is a fun, campy classic, drawing genuine thrills from its mindless ultra-violence."{{citeweb|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/death_race_2000/|title=Death Race 2000 (1975)|website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=4 April 2018}} The film has long been regarded as a cult hit, and was often viewed as superior to ''[[Rollerball (1975 film)|Rollerball]]'', a much more expensive major studio drama released later in the same year; another [[dystopia]]n science-fiction sports film similarly focusing on the use of dangerous sports as an "opiate". ===Accolades=== The film is recognized by [[American Film Institute]] in these lists: * 2001: [[AFI's 100 Years...100 Thrills]] – Nominated{{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/100Years/thrills400.pdf |title=AFI's 100 Years...100 Thrills Nominees |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2016-08-20}} ==Home media== [[Shout! Factory]] released a Deluxe Edition [[DVD]] and [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] on June 22, 2010 in [[DVD region code|region 1/A]].{{cite web|last=Creepy |first=Uncle |url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/36732/the-original-death-race-gets-deluxe-blu-ray-and-dvd-treatment-and-more-corman-classics-co |title=The Original Death Race Gets the Deluxe Blu-ray and DVD Treatment and More Corman Classics to Come! |publisher=Dreadcentral.com |date=2010-04-01 |accessdate=2011-03-21}} Previous editions were released on DVD and [[VHS]] by Buena Vista Home Entertainment and [[New Concorde]], among others.{{cite web|title=DVD releases for: Death Race 2000|url=http://www.allmovie.com/dvd/releases/death-race-2000-12891|publisher=allmovie.com|accessdate=31 July 2010}} ==Legacy== ===Comic book series=== A [[comic book]] [[sequel]] titled ''Death Race 2020'' was published in 1995 by [[Roger Corman]]'s short-lived ''Roger Corman's Cosmic Comics'' imprint. It was written by [[Pat Mills]] of ''[[2000 AD (comics)|2000 AD]]'' fame, with art by [[Kevin O'Neill (comics)|Kevin O'Neill]]. The pair had already worked together on several comics, including ''[[Marshal Law (comics)|Marshal Law]]''. The comic book, as the title indicates, took place 20 years after the film ended and dealt with Frankenstein's return to the race. New racer characters introduced included [[Kenny Howard|Von Dutch]], the Alcoholic, Happy the Clown, Steppenwolf, Rick Rhesus and Harry Carrie. The comic book series lasted eight issues before being cancelled. ===Remake series=== [[Paul W. S. Anderson]] directed a [[Film remake|remake]] entitled ''[[Death Race (film)|Death Race]]'', which was released August 22, 2008, starring [[Jason Statham]]. The remake began production in late August 2007.{{cite news |last1=Graser |first1=Marc |last2=Garrett |first2=Diane |title = Film: Universal Restarts 'Spy Hunter', Paul W.S. Anderson To Direct Adaptation |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117966153.html?categoryid=13&cs=1&query=death+race |accessdate=2007-06-01 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date=2007-06-01}} Besides Statham, this new version also stars [[Ian McShane]], [[Joan Allen]], and [[Tyrese Gibson]].{{cite web |first= |last= |authorlink= |title=Ian McShane Joins ''Death Race'' |url= http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=23127 |publisher= ComingSoon.net, sourcing ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' |date= Aug 8, 2007 |accessdate=2007-08-08 }} It also includes a [[Cameo appearance|cameo]] (by [[voice-over]]) of [[David Carradine]] reprising his role as Frankenstein. Two [[Direct-to-video|direct-to-DVD]] [[prequels]] titled ''[[Death Race 2]]'' (2011) and ''[[Death Race 3: Inferno]]'' (2013) starring [[Luke Goss]], [[Tanit Phoenix]], [[Danny Trejo]] and [[Ving Rhames]] and a direct-to-DVD sequel titled ''[[Death Race: Beyond Anarchy]]'' (2018) were also produced. ===Sequel=== An official film sequel to the original film, ''[[Death Race 2050]]'' was produced by [[Roger Corman]]{{cite web|last=Alexander|first=Chris|title=Roger Corman Turns 90! Releases BTS Stills from DEATH RACE 2050!|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/horror/news/749108-roger-corman-turns-90-releases-bts-stills-death-race-2050|publisher=[[ComingSoon.net]]|date=April 6, 2016|accessdate=January 16, 2017}} and released in early 2017.{{cite web|last=Alexander|first=Chris|title=Roger Corman’s Death Race 2050 Blu-ray Review|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/horror/reviews/801345-roger-cormans-death-race-2050-blu-ray-review|publisher=[[ComingSoon.net]]|date=January 10, 2017|accessdate=January 16, 2017}} ===Other references=== * It was often reported that the 1976 video game ''[[Death Race (1976 video game)|Death Race]]'' (which was [[Death Race (1990 video game)|remade in 1990]]) was a licensed adaptation of ''Death Race 2000'', but the developers have denied that this was the case.{{Cite web |url=http://allincolorforaquarter.blogspot.com/2013/05/the-ultimate-so-far-history-of-exidy_24.html|title=The Golden Age Arcade Historian: The Ultimate (So Far) History of Exidy - Part 2|last=Smith|first=Keith|date=2013-05-24|website=The Golden Age Arcade Historian|access-date=2017-11-06}} * The video game ''[[Carmageddon]]'' was developed under the ''Death Race 2000'' license, in anticipation of the planned film sequel. When the sequel was cancelled, the game dropped the ''Death Race 2000'' license.{{cite web | url=http://www.next-gen.biz/features/making-of%C3%B6-carmageddon |title=The Making Of... Carmageddon |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120509211733/http://www.edge-online.com/features/making-of%c3%b6-carmageddon |archivedate=2012-05-09 |publisher=[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]]}} * At the beginning of the song "Isle of Dead" by [[Buckethead]], a short excerpt from the film can be heard. * In the 1992 Roger Corman-produced film ''[[Munchie Strikes Back]]'', clips from the film (including the helicopter chase) are used as part of a video game called ''Death Race 2000''. * ''[[The Alex Jones Show]]'' frequently uses the audio of the scene where Harold explains the scoring system as a [[Bumper (broadcasting)|bumper]]. The program also airs similar bumpers which feature clips from other dystopian films such as ''[[Soylent Green]]'' and ''[[They Live]]''. ==See also== * [[List of American films of 1975]] * ''[[The 10th Victim]]'' * ''[[Battle Royale (film)]]'' * ''[[Deathsport]]'' * ''[[The Cars That Ate Paris]]'' * ''[[The Running Man (1987 film)|The Running Man]]'' * ''[[Mad Max]]'' * ''[[The Road Warrior]]'' * ''[[The Blood of Heroes]]'' * ''[[Quintet (film)|Quintet]]'' * ''[[The Hunger Games (film)|The Hunger Games]]'' ;Video games * ''[[Roadwar 2000]]'' * ''[[Death Rally]]'' * ''[[Twisted Metal]]'' ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0072856|Death Race 2000}} *{{tcmdb title|23983|Death Race 2000}} *{{Allmovie title|12891|Death Race 2000}} *{{rotten-tomatoes|death_race_2000|Death Race 2000}} {{Death Race Franchise}} {{Paul Bartel}} {{Roger Corman}} {{Charles B. Griffith}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Death Race 2000}} [[Category:Death Race]] [[Category:1975 films]] [[Category:1970s action films]] [[Category:1970s road movies]] [[Category:1970s science fiction films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American independent films]] [[Category:American road movies]] [[Category:American satirical films]] [[Category:American science fiction action films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Paul Bartel]] [[Category:Screenplays by Charles B. Griffith]] [[Category:Films produced by Roger Corman]] [[Category:Films based on science fiction short stories]] [[Category:Auto racing films]] [[Category:Dystopian films]] [[Category:Films set in 2000]] [[Category:Films set in the future]] [[Category:New World Pictures films]] [[Category:Fictional motorsports]] [[Category:Motorsports in fiction]] [[Category:Politics in fiction]] [[Category:Sports in fiction]]

{{see also|2004 in sports|Portal:Sports}} {{Events by month|2004|in sports}}__NOTOC__ {{Month year in topic|December 2004|sports|anchor=mdy}} {| class="infobox" style="width:18em" | ==Deaths== {{main article|Deaths in December 2004}} * [[December 26|26]] [[Reggie White]] * [[December 24|24]] [[Johnny Oates]] * [[December 22|22]] [[Doug Ault]] * [[December 18|18]] [[Vijay Hazare]] * [[December 16|16]] [[Ted Abernathy]] * [[December 16|16]] [[Bobby Mattick]] * [[December 14|14]] [[Rod Kanehl]] * [[December 13|13]] [[Andre Rodgers]] * [[December 11|11]] [[Arthur Lydiard]] * [[December 11|11]] [[Bum Bright|Harvey "Bum" Bright]] * [[December 10|10]] [[Bob King (basketball)|Bob King]] * [[December 6|6]] [[Raymond Goethals]] * [[December 5|5]] [[Christiano Junior]] * [[December 5|5]] [[Hicham Zerouali]] * [[December 4|4]] [[Tom Fitzgerald (soccer coach)|Tom Fitzgerald]] <!-- Please add new items at the top of the list --> |}
==December 31, 2004== *[[Cricket]]: Many of the world's leading cricket teams have pledged money for the [[humanitarian response to the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake|humanitarian effort in South-East Asia]]: **The [[English cricket team]] have personally pledged £15,000, with the Professional Cricketers' Association adding a further £5,000 **The [[Australian cricket team]] donated their prize money from the [[Melbourne]] [[Test cricket|test match]] **[[South Africa national cricket team|South Africa's]] cricket board, [[Cricket South Africa]] will make a donation, together with the sponsors of their test series against England **The [[Board of Control for Cricket in India]] has agreed to give Rs10million (£120,000), with the [[Indian cricket team]] donating their fees from their next [[One Day International]] **[[Bangladesh national cricket team|Bangladesh]] have agreed to donate the gate receipts from their forthcoming series at home against [[Zimbabwe national cricket team|Zimbabwe]], estimated to be US$10,000 **The [[Federation of International Cricketers' Associations]] has proposed a one-day match on [[January 11|11]] or 12 January to raise more funds. All teams have supported the proposal, although English, South African, Bangladeshi and Zimabwean players are likely to be unavailable because of ongoing tour commitments. The ICC is likely to endorse any such game. [http://uk.cricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/CRICKET_NEWS/2004/DEC/144112_ENG_30DEC2004.html] [http://uk.cricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/CRICKET_NEWS/2004/DEC/144741_BDESHZIM2004-05_31DEC2004.html] [http://uk.cricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/CRICKET_NEWS/2004/DEC/144779_IND_31DEC2004.html] [http://uk.cricinfo.com/link_to_database/ARCHIVE/CRICKET_NEWS/2004/DEC/144647_WCI_31DEC2004.html (Cricinfo)] *In the [[United Kingdom|UK's]] [[British honours system|New Year's Honours]], [[Matthew Pinsent]] is [[Order of the British Empire|knighted]]; [[Kelly Holmes]] and [[Tanni Grey-Thompson]] become [[Order of the British Empire|Dames]]. Other Olympians and sportspeople are also recognised. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/front_page/4135077.stm (BBC)] *[[College football]] [[NCAA football bowl games, 2004-05|bowl games]]: **The [[University of Minnesota Twin Cities|Minnesota Golden Gophers]] defeat the [[University of Alabama|Alabama Crimson Tide]] 20–16 in the [[Music City Bowl]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=243660135 (ESPN)] **The [[Arizona State University|Arizona State Sun Devils]] defeat the [[Purdue University|Purdue Boilermakers]] 27–23 in a back-and-forth matchup in the [[Sun Bowl]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=243662509 (ESPN)] **The [[University of Louisville|Louisville Cardinals]] defeat the [[Boise State University|Boise State Broncos]] 44–40 in the [[Liberty Bowl]], ending the Broncos' 22-game winning streak. [http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=243660097 (ESPN)] **The [[University of Miami|Miami Hurricanes]] defeat the [[University of Florida|Florida Gators]] 27–10 in the [[Peach Bowl]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=243660057 (ESPN)]
==December 30, 2004== *[[Cricket]]: [[South Africa national cricket team|South Africa]] hold out in the final day of the second [[test cricket|Test]] against [[England cricket team|England]] to secure a draw, bringing to an end England's eight-game winning streak. The final score: England 139 & 570–9 dec, South Africa 332 & 290–8; bad light stops play with 15 overs remaining. England are the only team to remain unbeaten at Test cricket throughout 2004 – winning 11 times, drawing twice. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/shared/fds/hi/statistics/cricket/scorecards/2004/12/7345/html/scorecard.stm (BBC)] *[[College football]] [[NCAA football bowl games, 2004-05|bowl games]]: **The [[Boston College|Boston College Eagles]] defeat the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill|North Carolina Tar Heels]], 37–24, in the [[Continental Tire Bowl]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=243650153 (ESPN)] **The [[United States Naval Academy|Navy Midshipmen]] complete their first 10-win season since 1905 by defeating the [[University of New Mexico|New Mexico Lobos]] 34–19 in the [[Emerald Bowl]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=243652426 (ESPN)] **The [[Texas Tech University|Texas Tech Red Raiders]] upset the [[University of California, Berkeley|Cal Golden Bears]] 45–31 in the [[Holiday Bowl]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=243650025 (ESPN)] **The [[Northern Illinois University|Northern Illinois Huskies]] defeat the [[Troy University|Troy Trojans]] 34–21 in the [[Silicon Valley Football Classic]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=243652653 (ESPN)] *[[National Basketball Association|NBA]]: **The [[Seattle SuperSonics]] defeat the [[Atlanta Hawks]], 94–79, [[Philips Arena|in Atlanta]]. [http://www.nba.com/games/20041230/SEAATL/recap.html (NBA)] **The [[New Jersey Nets]] play the [[Indiana Pacers]], [[Continental Airlines Arena|in New Jersey]]. **The [[Detroit Pistons]] play the [[Miami Heat]], [[The Palace of Auburn Hills|in Detroit]]. **The [[San Antonio Spurs]] play the [[Portland Trail Blazers]], [[Rose Garden Arena|in Portland]]. *[[Football (soccer)]]: **[[Real Madrid]] announce that former [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] [[Coach (sport)|coach]] [[Wanderley Luxemburgo]] will be their new coach, replacing [[Mariano Garcia Remon]]. Luxemburgo will be Real's third coach this season. He leaves [[Santos Futebol Clube|Santos]], which he recently led to the Brazilian championship. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/4134721.stm (BBC)] **[[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United's]] 19-year-old star [[Wayne Rooney]] has been given a three-match ban by [[the Football Association]] for violent behaviour after TV images showed him shoving Bolton defender [[Tal Ben Haim]] in the face. Haim has also been criticised for poor behaviour, as he was judged to exaggerate the episode. [[Alex Ferguson]] has criticised the [[The Football Association|FA]] for their handling of the case. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/4120513.stm (BBC)]
==December 29, 2004== *[[Cricket]]: **[[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] (379 and 127 for 1) beat [[Pakistan national cricket team|Pakistan]] (341 and 163) by 9 wickets at the [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]], [[Melbourne]], Australia to lead the 3 [[test cricket|test]] series 2–0. [[Ricky Ponting]], the Australian captain, later suggests that [[Shoaib Akhtar]] did not bowl as well as he should have done. [http://uk.cricinfo.com/link_to_database/ARCHIVE/CRICKET_NEWS/2004/DEC/142190_AUS_29DEC2004.html (Cricinfo)] **[[Sri Lanka national cricket team|Sri Lanka]] postpone their tour of [[New Zealand national cricket team|New Zealand]] to return home. The decision is taken after a [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake|tsunami]] struck the eastern [[Sri Lanka]]n coast, killing tens of thousands. The New Zealand Cricket Board and the [[International Cricket Council]] support the move. [[Muttiah Muralitharan]], the second highest wicket-taker in [[Test cricket|test match]] history, avoided the tsunami striking [[Galle]] by minutes. The Test match ground in [[Galle]] has been devastated. [http://uk.cricinfo.com/link_to_database/ARCHIVE/CRICKET_NEWS/2004/DEC/143315_NZSL2004-05_29DEC2004.html (Cricinfo)] [http://www.icc-cricket.com/db/ARCHIVE/CRICKET_NEWS/2004/DEC/143441_ICC-MEDIA_29DEC2004.html (ICC)] **[[Zimbabwe national cricket team|Zimbabwe]]'s arrival in [[Bangladesh national cricket team|Bangladesh]] has been postponed by two days as a result of disruption to flight schedules from India into [[Bangladesh]] caused by a [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake|tsunami]] striking the region. ==December 26, 2004== *[[National Football League|NFL]]: **[[Reggie White]], who was regarded as the dominant defensive lineman in the NFL in the 1990s as a player for the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] and [[Green Bay Packers]], dies of a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]] at age 43. The Colts overcome a 15-point deficit to beat the [[San Diego Chargers]] 34–31 [[RCA Dome|in Indianapolis]]. The Colts clinch the 3rd seed in the AFC, while the Chargers will be the 4th seed. ==December 15, 2004== *[[National Basketball Association|NBA]]: ** [[Carmelo Anthony]] makes a shot with 3.6 seconds left in the game, and [[Paul Pierce]] misses a subsequent three-point shot attempt, as the [[Denver Nuggets]] defeat the [[Boston Celtics]], 100–99. [[Andre Miller]] of the Nuggets made a shot from the opponent's free throw line as time expired during the first quarter, but the shot was discounted because it was apparently taken after time had expired in that quarter.[http://aol.nba.com/games/20041215/DENBOS/recap.html (NBA)] ** The defending-champion [[Detroit Pistons]] defeat the [[New York Knicks]], 94–93, at New York, when [[Chauncey Billups]] makes two free throws with less than three seconds to go. The Pistons were down by 16 points, 56–40, at halftime. Pistons coach [[Larry Brown (basketball)|Larry Brown]] records his 944th win as a coach, tying [[Bill Fitch]] for 4th in NBA history. [http://aol.nba.com/games/20041215/DETNYK/recap.html (NBA)] ** [[Dan Dickau]] makes a three-point shot as the third quarter is winding down and gets fouled, making the free throw for a four-point play in what would eventually be the [[New Orleans Hornets]]' first home victory of the season, a 98–89 defeat of the [[Golden State Warriors]]. The Hornets also snap an eleven-game losing streak. [http://aol.nba.com/games/20041215/GSWNOH/recap.html (NBA)] ** [[Steve Francis]] misses a three-point shot as time runs off, and the [[San Antonio Spurs]] hold on for a 94–91 win over the [[Orlando Magic]]. [http://aol.nba.com/games/20041215/ORLSAS/recap.html (NBA)] ** [[Jeff McInnis]] and [[Drew Gooden]] complete an unlikely five-point play with time running down in the third quarter (McInnis made a three-point shot, followed by a steal and a basket by Gooden) as the [[Cleveland Cavaliers]] beat the [[Portland Trail Blazers]], 112–88. The Cavaliers extend their home winning streak to nine games, their longest home winning streak since 1993. [http://aol.nba.com/games/20041215/PORCLE/recap.html (NBA)] *[[Boxing]]: [[Oscar De La Hoya]] announces plans to return to the Welterweight division, where he was the [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] world champion from 1997 to 1999 and in 2000. [http://aolsvc.news.aol.com/sports/article.adp?id=20041215112609990002 (AOL)] *[[Tennis]]: Rumors spread that former tennis star [[Anna Kournikova]] has secretly married her long-time boyfriend, [[Enrique Iglesias]].[http://aolsvc.news.aol.com/sports/article.adp?id=20041214173409990019 (AOL)] *[[Biathlon]]: The men's 10 km Sprint at WC 3 in [[Östersund]], Sweden, ends with [[Stian Eckhoff]] (NOR) getting his first World Cup race victory, and with the runner-up, teammate [[Frode Andresen]], making his best result this season, using 10 seconds more than Eckhoff. [[Sergei Rozhkov]] (Сергей Рожков) of Russia gets the third place, 1 second after Andresen. [http://biathlonworld.siwidata.info/data/archives.aspx?RaceId=BT0405SWRLCP03SMSP (IBU/EBU results)] *[[Cross-country skiing]]: In the [[Cross-country skiing World Cup medalists|World Cup]] 6×1.2 km classical technique team sprint event in [[Asiago]], Italy, the ladies' race results in an all-Nordic podium, as it is won by Norway I, ([[Marit Bjørgen]], [[Ella Gjømle]]), one second before Finland I ([[Aino-Kaisa Saarinen]], [[Virpi Kuitunen]]), while Sweden I ([[Elin Ek (cross-country skier)|Elin Ek]], [[Anna Olsson (skier)|Anna Dahlberg]]) finishes third. [http://www.fis-ski.com/uk/604/610.html?sector=CC&raceid=7998 (FIS-Ski results)] The men's race is won by Norway I ([[Tor Arne Hetland]], [[Jens Arne Svartedal]]), finishing roughly 3 seconds before Russia I ([[Nikolay Pankratov]], [[Vasily Rochev (skier, born 1980)|Vasily Rochev]]) (Николай Панкратов, Василий Рочев), who comes in 3 seconds in front of Norway II ([[Trond Iversen]], [[Børre Næss]]). [http://www.fis-ski.com/uk/604/610.html?sector=CC&raceid=7999 (FIS-Ski results)] *[[Cricket]]: The [[England and Wales Cricket Board]] announces new broadcasting deals with [[BSkyB]], [[Five (TV)|Five]], the [[BBC]] and [[TalkSPORT]]. From 2006 to 2009, all [[England cricket team|England]] home [[Test cricket|test match]]es and [[One Day International]]s, plus domestic competition coverage will be televised on Sky Sports, with highlights on [[Five (TV)|Five]]. ''[[Test Match Special]]'' survives, as the [[BBC]] retains exclusive rights for radio coverage to home internationals, and non-exclusive rights to domestic county games. [[TalkSPORT]] has won non-exclusive rights to radio coverage of [[Twenty20]] games. The deals will earn English cricket £220m over 2006–09. ==December 12, 2004== *[[Rodeo]]: Ropers [[Speedy Williams]] and [[Rich Skelton]] win their record eighth consecutive world team roping title at the [[National Finals Rodeo]] in [[Las Vegas]]. [[Clay Tryan]] and [[Michael Jones (rodeo performer)|Michael Jones]] won the aggregate title, while [[Dustin Elliott]] took the individual world title, hos first.[http://www.azcentral.com/sports/azetc/articles/1213rodeo1213.html (AZ Central)] *[[College basketball]]: [[Duke University]] coach [[Mike Krzyzewski]] leads his team to his 700th career victory with an 82–54 win over the [[University of Toledo]]. Krzyzewski is only the 17th coach in [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] history to lead one team to 700 wins. [http://sports.espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=243470150 (ESPN)] *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/front_page/4085337.stm BBC Sports Personality of the Year Awards]: **Sports Personality of the Year (Winner): [[Athletics (track and field)|Athlete]] [[Kelly Holmes]] **Sports Personality of the Year (Second place): [[Rower]] [[Matthew Pinsent]] **Sports Personality of the Year (Third place): [[Cricketer]] [[Andrew Flintoff]] **Overseas Personality of the Year: [[Tennis]] player [[Roger Federer]] **Unsung hero: [[Abdullah Ben-Kmayal]] **Coach of the Year: [[Arsène Wenger]], manager of [[Arsenal F.C.]] **Team of the Year: Great Britain Olympic Men's Coxless 4 [[Sport rowing|rowing]] team **Helen Rollason Award for courage in the face of adversity: [[Kirsty Howard]] **Lifetime Achievement: [[Cricketer]] [[Ian Botham]] **Young Personality of the Year: [[Tennis]] player [[Andy Murray|Andrew Murray]] *[[Biathlon]]: The [[Holmenkollen ski arena|Holmenkollen]] BWC event's final day features two Pursuit races, of which the ladies' 10 km race is won by [[Sandrine Bailly]] (FRA), with yesterday's winner [[Olga Zaitseva]] (Ольга Зайцева) (RUS) finishing second, and [[Olena Zubrilova]] (Олена Зубрилова) (BLR) getting the 3rd place. [http://biathlonworld.siwidata.info/data/archives.aspx?RaceId=BT0405SWRLCP02SWPU (IBU/EBU Results)] In the men's 12.5 km race, [[Sven Fischer]] (GER) takes his 9th victory at Holmenkollen, beating [[Raphaël Poirée]] (FRA) by 8.6 seconds, and yesterday's Sprint winner, [[Ole Einar Bjørndalen]], by 16.3 seconds. [http://biathlonworld.siwidata.info/data/archives.aspx?RaceId=BT0405SWRLCP02SMPU (IBU/EBU Results)] *[[Cross-country skiing]]: In the World Cup event at [[Fiemme Valley]], Italy, Russia's #I team ([[Larisa Kurkina]], [[Natalia Baranova-Masolkina]], [[Yevgeniya Medvedeva-Arbuzova]], [[Yuliya Chepalova]]) (Лариса Куркина, Наталия Баранова-Масолкина, Евгения Медведева-Абрузова, Юлия Чепалова) wins the ladies' 4×5 km Classical/Free technique relay, with Germany ([[Manuela Henkel]], [[Claudia Künzel]], [[Stefanie Böhler]], [[Evi Sachenbacher]]) coming in second, and Norway ([[Kine Beate Bjørnås]], [[Vibeke Skofterud]], [[Hilde Gjermundshaug Pedersen|Hilde G. Pedersen]], [[Marit Bjørgen]]) finishing third. [http://www.fis-ski.com/uk/604/610.html?sector=CC&raceid=7990 (FIS-Ski Results)] The men's 4×10 km C/F race is won by Norway I ([[Jens Arne Svartedal]], [[Odd-Bjørn Hjelmeset]], [[Frode Estil]], [[Tore Ruud Hofstad]]), in a [[photo finish]] victory in front of Italy I ([[Giorgio Di Centa]], [[Fulvio Valbusa]], [[Pietro Piller Cottrer]], [[Cristian Zorzi]]), half a second before France ([[Christophe Perrillat]], [[Vincent Vittoz]], [[Emmanuel Jonnier]], [[Alexandre Rousselet]]). [http://www.fis-ski.com/uk/604/610.html?sector=CC&raceid=7991 (FIS-Ski Results)] *[[Football (soccer)]]: **[[Newell's Old Boys]] won its 5th [[Argentine Primera División|Argentine League]] title in spite of losing 0 - 1 to [[Club Atlético Independiente|Independiente]]. **A bomb warning forces the evacuation of over 70,000 people from [[Real Madrid]]'s [[Santiago Bernabéu Stadium]] two minutes before the end of the [[La Liga]] match with [[Real Sociedad]]. The two teams were drawing 1–1 at the time. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/4090669.stm (BBC)]. The Spanish Football Association have announced that the remaining 2 minutes 40 seconds, plus 4 minutes' stoppage time, will be played at 6 p.m. on 5 January 2005. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/4091901.stm (BBC)] **[[2004 Tiger Cup]] championship, First Round: ***Group B: [[East Timor national football team|Timor Leste]] 0 – 8 [[Thailand national football team|Thailand]] ***Group B: [[Myanmar national football team|Myanmar]] 1 – 0 [[Malaysia national football team|Malaysia]] **The [[Indiana University Bloomington|Indiana Hoosiers]] defeat the [[University of California, Santa Barbara|UCSB Gauchos]] 3–2 on [[penalty shootout (football)|penalties]] (they drew 1–1) to win the [[NCAA Men's Soccer Championship|NCAA Division I men's soccer championship]]. *[[National Football League]], Week 14: **[[Peyton Manning]] comes within two [[touchdown]] passes of [[Dan Marino]]'s single-season record as he leads the [[Indianapolis Colts]] to a 23–14 win over the [[Houston Texans]] and the [[American Football Conference|AFC]] South division championship. Manning went 26 for 33 and threw for 298 yards. [http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=241212034 (ESPN)] **Peyton's younger brother, [[Eli Manning]], did not have as good a day as he threw for only 27 yards and completed just four of 18 passes as the [[New York Giants]] fell to the [[Baltimore Ravens]] 37–14. [http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=241212033 (ESPN)] **[[Michael Vick]] and [[T. J. Duckett]] lead the [[Atlanta Falcons]] to the [[NFC South]] championship with a 35–10 win over the [[Oakland Raiders]]. Duckett ran for a team record four [[touchdown]]s in the game. [http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=241212001 (ESPN)] **[[Jerome Bettis]] rushes for 57 yards and throws a 10-yard [[touchdown]] pass as the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] defeat the [[New York Jets]] 17–6 to win the [[AFC North]] championship. [http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=241212023 (ESPN)] **The [[New England Patriots]] clinch the AFC East division championship with a 35–28 win over the [[Cincinnati Bengals]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=241212017 (ESPN)]
==December 11, 2004== *[[Manuel Pacquiao|Manny Pacquiao]] defeats boxer [[Fahsan 3K Battery]] of [[Thailand]]. Fahsan was knocked out with a fourth knockdown. The fight was a tune-up game to an upcoming rematch with [[Juan Manuel Márquez]] in February to unify the [[International Boxing Federation|IBF]] and [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] world Featherweight titles. [http://news.inq7.net/sports/index.php?index=1&story_id=20962 (PDI)] *[[College basketball]]: [[University of Arizona]] head coach [[Lute Olson]] coaches his 1,000th career victory, a 67–62 win over the [[University of Utah]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=243460012 (ESPN)] *[[National Basketball Association|NBA]]: **[[Brad Miller (basketball player)|Brad Miller]] of the [[Sacramento Kings]] makes four straight free throws in the closing seconds, as the [[Sacramento Kings]] defeat the [[Indiana Pacers]], 97–92, in overtime. It is the Pacers' seventh straight defeat. [http://aol.nba.com/games/20041211/SACIND/recap.html (NBA)] **In a match between cross-town rivals, the [[Los Angeles Lakers]] defeat the [[Los Angeles Clippers]], 89–87. [http://aol.nba.com/games/20041211/LALLAC/boxscore.html (NBA)] *[[Biathlon]]: The second day of WC 2 at [[Holmenkollen ski arena|Holmenkollen]], Norway, starts with the women's 7.5 km Sprint race being won by [[Olga Zaitseva]] (Cyrillic: Ольга Зайцева) (RUS), with [[Olga Pyleva]] (Cyrillics: Ольга Пылева) (RUS) and [[Tadeja Brankovic]] (SLO) tying for the 2nd place. [http://biathlonworld.siwidata.info/data/archives.aspx?RaceId=BT0405SWRLCP02SWSP (IBU/EBU Results)] After the men's 10 km Sprint, the podium is occupied by [[Ole Einar Bjørndalen]] (NOR) at the top, [[Raphaël Poirée]] (FRA) at the next place, and Bjørndalen's teammate [[Halvard Hanevold]] at third. [http://biathlonworld.siwidata.info/data/archives.aspx?RaceId=BT0405SWRLCP02SMSP (IBU/EBU Results)] The Sprint races' results determine the time differenced starting order of tomorrow's Pursuits. *[[Boxing]]: [[Vitali Klitschko]] retains his [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] world Heavyweight title with an eighth-round knockout over [[Danny Williams (boxer)|Danny Williams]], and [[Miguel Cotto]] retains his [[WBO]] world Jr. Welterweight title with a sixth-round knockout win over [[Randall Bailey]], in [[Las Vegas]]. [http://aolsvc.news.aol.com/sports/article.adp?id=20041212002409990001 (AOL)] *[[Cricket]]: [[India national cricket team|India]]n batsman [[Sachin Tendulkar]] equals [[Sunil Gavaskar]]'s world record of 34 [[Test cricket|test match]] centuries in the first test against [[Bangladesh national cricket team|Bangladesh]] at [[Dhaka]]. [http://uk.cricinfo.com/db/NEW/LIVE/frames/IND_BDESH_T1_10-14DEC2004.html (Cricinfo)] *[[Cross-country skiing]]: Starting off the weekend's World Cup event at [[Fiemme Valley]], Italy, [[Marit Bjørgen]] (NOR) consolidates her total WC lead by winning the ladies' 2×7.5 km Double Pursuit race. [[Kristina Šmigun]] (EST) and [[Gabriella Paruzzi]] (ITA) follow on the next two places, 0.34 and 2.57 seconds later, respectively. [http://www.fis-ski.com/uk/604/610.html?sector=CC&raceid=7988 (FIS-Ski Results)] The men's 2×15 km race is won by WC leader [[Axel Teichmann]] (GER), beating teammate [[Jens Filbrich]] and Frenchman [[Vincent Vittoz]] in a spurt where the six first skiers finish within the same second. [http://www.fis-ski.com/uk/604/610.html?sector=CC&raceid=7989 (FIS-Ski Results)] *[[College football]]: **[[Matt Leinart]], quarterback of the [[University of Southern California]], wins the [[Heisman Trophy]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/awards04/news/story?id=1944242 (ESPN)] **[[Valdosta State University]] defeats [[Pittsburg State University]], 36–31 to win the [[NCAA Division II national football championship]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=1920965 (ESPN)] *[[Football (soccer)|Football]]: [[2004 Tiger Cup]] championship, First Round **Group A: [[Laos national football team|Laos]] 0 – 1 [[Cambodia national football team|Cambodia]] **Group A: [[Vietnam national football team|Vietnam]] 0 – 3 [[Indonesia national football team|Indonesia]]
==December 10, 2004== * [[Ice hockey]]: The [[London Knights]] obtain sole possiession of the [[Canadian Hockey League]] record for the longest [[unbeaten streak]], with their 30-game run surpassing the mark set by the [[Brandon Wheat Kings]] following a rare 0–0 tie in an [[Ontario Hockey League]] game against the [[Guelph Storm]]. Guelph goaltender [[Adam Dennis]] is named first star, having stopped 48 shots from the Knights. [http://story.news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&cid=2150&ncid=2150&e=4&u=/cpress/20041211/ca_pr_on_sp/hky_chl_record (CP)] * [[Fox-hunting]]: The [[Countryside Alliance]] announces that 250 hunts will meet legally on 19 February, the day after fox-hunting becomes illegal in England and [[Wales]]. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/4086133.stm (BBC)] * [[Cricket]] **Rod Marsh steps down as director of the England and Wales Cricket Board's academy after 4 years in charge. [http://uk.cricinfo.com/link_to_database/ARCHIVE/CRICKET_NEWS/2004/DEC/125648_ENG_10DEC2004.html (Cricinfo)] **The third [[One Day International]] between [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] and [[New Zealand national cricket team|New Zealand]] at [[Brisbane]], Australia is called off without a ball being bowled because of rain. The 3 match series finishes level at 1–1. [http://live.cricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/2004-05/NZ_IN_AUS/SCORECARDS/NZ_AUS_ODI3_10DEC2004.html (Cricinfo)] **[[Anil Kumble]] becomes India's highest [[Wicket#Dismissing a batsman|wicket taker]] when he trapped Mohammad Rafique of [[Bangladesh]] to surpass [[Kapil Dev]]'s haul of 435 [[wickets]] on the first day of their match in [[Dhaka]]. * [[Football (soccer)|Football]]: [[2004 Tiger Cup]] championship, First Round **Group B: [[Thailand national football team|Thailand]] 1 – 1 [[Myanmar national football team|Myanmar]] **Group B: [[Malaysia national football team|Malaysia]] 4 – 1 [[Philippines national football team|Philippines]]
==December 9, 2004==
*[[Ice hockey]]: **The Worldstars team consisting of [[2004–05 NHL lockout|locked-out]] players from North American [[National Hockey League]] starts a 7-country, 10-game charity tour against European teams, with a 4–2 win over Riga 2000 team in [[Riga]], [[Latvia]]. [http://www.cbc.ca/sports/story/2004/12/09/worldstars041209.html (CBC)] **The [[National Hockey League]] labor negotiations restart, after the players [[labor union|union]], [[NHL Players' Association|NHLPA]], making the first new offer in three months. The offer includes players accepting a 24% one-time salary cut. [http://www.cbc.ca/sports/story/2004/12/09/nhlpa_nhltalks041209.html (CBC)] *[[Biathlon]]: In the [[Biathlon World Cup|WC 2]] event at [[Holmenkollen ski arena|Holmenkollen]] in [[Oslo]], Norway, the women's 15 km Individual race is won by [[Martina Glagow]] (GER), while [[Svetlana Ishmouratova]] (Светлана Ишмуратова) (RUS) gets the 2nd place, and [[Magdalena Gwizdon]] (POL) comes in 3rd. The third to finish is [[Tomasz Sikora]] (POL). ==December 5, 2004== *[[Biathlon]]: At the last day of [[Biathlon World Cup|WC 1]] at [[Øystre Slidre|Beitostølen]], Norway, the women's 4×6 km Relay is won by Russia, finishing 11 seconds before runner-up Germany, and one minute before France. [http://biathlonworld.siwidata.info/data/archives.aspx?RaceId=BT0405SWRLCP01SWRL (IBU/EBU Results)] In the men's 4×7.5 km Relay, Norway wins by a large margin, almost one minute and a half before Germany's team, who in turn is followed 13 seconds later by Russia. [http://biathlonworld.siwidata.info/data/archives.aspx?RaceId=BT0405SWRLCP01SMRL (IBU/EBU Results)] *[[Cricket]]: **[[England cricket team|England]] beat [[Zimbabwe national cricket team|Zimbabwe]] by 74 runs in the fourth [[One Day International]] at [[Bulawayo]], [[Zimbabwe]] to win the 4 match series 4–0. Zimbabwe have now lost 17 games in a row.[http://uk.cricinfo.com/link_to_database/ARCHIVE/CRICKET_NEWS/2004/DEC/120053_ZIMENG2004-05_05DEC2004.html (Cricinfo)] **[[New Zealand national cricket team|New Zealand]] beat [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] by 4 wickets with 2 balls remaining in the first [[One Day International]] match at the Docklands ([[Telstra Dome]]) ground in [[Melbourne]], Australia to lead the 3 match series 1–0. [http://uk.cricinfo.com/link_to_database/ARCHIVE/CRICKET_NEWS/2004/DEC/119955_AUS_05DEC2004.html (Cricinfo)] *[[Cross-country skiing]]: On the final day of the week's World Cup event in [[Bern]], Switzerland, the Ladies' 6×1.1 km free technique Team Sprint race is won by Norway I, followed closely by Germany I, and with Italy I coming in 3rd, 2.5 seconds behind the Germans. [http://www.fis-ski.com/uk/604/610.html?sector=CC&raceid=7486 (FIS-Ski Results)] In the Men's race, Russia I finishes first, 0.3 seconds ahead of Norway I, who comes in a half-second before Italy I. [http://www.fis-ski.com/uk/604/610.html?sector=CC&raceid=7485 (FIS-Ski Results)] *[[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[College football|football]]: The matchups for the four [[Bowl Championship Series|BCS]] bowls are announced: **[[Orange Bowl (game)|Orange Bowl]] (national championship): [[University of Southern California|USC]] vs [[University of Oklahoma|Oklahoma]]. **[[Rose Bowl Game|Rose Bowl]]: [[University of Michigan|Michigan]] vs [[University of Texas at Austin|Texas]]. This breaks the traditional [[Big Ten Conference|Big 10]]–[[Pacific-10 Conference|Pac-10]] matchup. **[[Fiesta Bowl]]: [[University of Pittsburgh|Pittsburgh]] vs [[University of Utah|Utah]]. Utah becomes the first team from a mid-major conference to play in a BCS bowl. **[[Sugar Bowl]]: [[Virginia Tech]] vs [[Auburn University|Auburn]]. [https://sports.yahoo.com/ncaaf/news?slug=ap-bcsrdp&prov=ap&type=lgns (AP)] *[[National Football League|NFL]], Week 13: **[[Jake Plummer]] of the [[Denver Broncos]] throws four interceptions in a 20–17 loss to the [[San Diego Chargers]]. [[Brett Favre]]'s streak of 36 consecutive games with a touchdown pass is snapped. [https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/recap?gid=20041205021 (AP)] **The [[Cincinnati Bengals]] beat a winning team on the road for the first time in 14 years. [[Shayne Graham]]'s last-second 24-yard field goal capped a 24-point fourth-quarter comeback as the Bengals defeat the [[Baltimore Ravens]] 27–26. [https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/recap?gid=20041205033 (AP)] **[[Peyton Manning]] throws three touchdown passes and [[Rob Morris (American football)|Rob Morris]] returns a blocked [[Field goal (football)|field goal]] attempt for a touchdown as the [[Indianapolis Colts]] beat the [[Tennessee Titans]] 51–24. [https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/recap?gid=20041205011 (AP)] **[[Terrence McGee]] of the [[Buffalo Bills]] returns the opening kickoff 104 yards for a touchdown in a 42–32 win over the [[Miami Dolphins]]. [https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/recap?gid=20041205015 (AP)] **[[Bethel Johnson]] of the [[New England Patriots]] also returns an opening kickoff for the touchdown, [[Randall Gay]] returns a fumble for a score, [[Corey Dillon]] rushes for two touchdowns and [[Tom Brady]] passes for one in a 42–15 win over the [[Cleveland Browns]]. [https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/recap?gid=20041205005 (AP)] **The [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] upset the [[Atlanta Falcons]], preventing them from clinching the NFC South title this week. [[Simeon Rice]] of the Bucs becomes just the 22nd player in NFL history to reach 100 [[quarterback sack]]s. [http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=241205027 (ESPN)] **The [[Chicago Bears]] upset the [[Minnesota Vikings]], 24–14. [http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=241205003 (ESPN)] *[[Boxing]]: The [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] announces it will organize tournaments around the world, to crown one world champion in each division, from each continent. [http://www.expressindia.com/fullstory.php?newsid=39216 (Indian Express)] [http://www.deccanherald.com/deccanherald/dec052004/i9.asp (Deccan Herald)]
==December 4, 2004== *[[National Basketball Association|NBA]]: Former [[Phoenix Suns]] and [[Arizona Diamondbacks]] ([[baseball]]) majority owner [[Jerry Colangelo]] is diagnosed with [[prostate cancer]].[http://aol.nba.com/suns/news/azcentral_bickley_041204.html (The Arizona Republic)] **[[Carmelo Anthony]] scores his 2,000th career point in a 104–95 [[Denver Nuggets]] victory over the [[Miami Heat]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/recap?gameId=241204007 (ESPN)] **[[Kevin Garnett]] ties the game with a basket with 26 seconds left in regulation, and the [[Minnesota Timberwolves]] snap a winning streak for the second night in a row, stopping the [[Los Angeles Clippers]] streak at five wins and raising their own streak to five wins in a row, with a 107–100 overtime victory.[http://aol.nba.com/games/20041204/MINLAC/recap.html (NBA)] **[[Tracy McGrady]] hits a shot with 26 seconds to go, giving the [[Houston Rockets]] a 77–76 win over the [[Philadelphia 76ers]]. [[Kyle Korver]] and [[Aaron McKie]] of the 76ers miss potential game winning shots as time expires. [http://aol.nba.com/games/20041204/PHIHOU/recap.html (AOL)] *[[Biathlon]]: In the WC 1 event [[Øystre Slidre|Beitostølen]], Norway, the women's 10 km Pursuit race is won by [[Uschi Disl]] (GER); her second victory at Beito in three days. [[Albina Akhatova]] (Албина Ахатова) (RUS) finishes 2nd, and [[Martina Glagow]] (GER) comes in 3rd. [http://biathlonworld.siwidata.info/data/archives.aspx?RaceId=BT0405SWRLCP01SWPU (IBU/EBU Results)] In the men's 12.5 km Pursuit, 10 years+ BWC veteran [[Sven Fischer]] (GER) wins, followed by [[Nikolay Kruglov, Jr.]] (Николай Кругов) (RUS), who beats fellow Russian [[Sergei Rozhkov]] by a tenth of a second for the 2nd place. [http://biathlonworld.siwidata.info/data/archives.aspx?RaceId=BT0405SWRLCP01SMPU (IBU/EBU Results)] The winner of Thursday's Sprint race for men, and thus start number one in the Pursuit, Ole Einar Bjørndalen (NOR), comes in no. 6, fronting a probably statistically unique cluster of five contestants from the same country placed contiguously on the result list. Bjørndalen loses his lead in the Biathlon World Cup to Kruglov (RUS), who has two 2nd places so far this BWC season. *[[Boxing]]: [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] world Lightweight champion [[José Luis Castillo]] retains his title by a split and controversial decision (scores of 116–112, 117–111 and 113–115) over former two time world Jr. Lightweight champion [[Joel Casamayor]]. [http://www.boxing-central.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=5404 (Boxing Central)] *[[Cricket]]: [[England cricket team|England]] beat [[Zimbabwe national cricket team|Zimbabwe]] by 8 wickets in the third [[One Day International]] at [[Bulawayo]], [[Zimbabwe]] to lead the four-match series 3–0. [http://uk.cricinfo.com/link_to_database/ARCHIVE/CRICKET_NEWS/2004/DEC/119352_ZIMENG2004-05_04DEC2004.html (Cricinfo)] *[[Cross-country skiing]]: In the [[Cross-country skiing World Cup medalists#Sprint 2|World Cup 2004/05]]'s second Sprint event, in [[Bern]], Switzerland, the 0.8 km Ladies' race is won by Norway's [[Marit Bjørgen]], with [[Stefanie Böhler]] (GER) and [[Ella Gjømle]] (NOR) coming in second and third. [http://www.fis-ski.com/uk/604/610.html?sector=CC&raceid=7484 (FIS-Ski Results)]. The 1.35 km Men's race is won by [[Tor Arne Hetland]] (NOR), with [[Thobias Fredriksson]] (SWE) and [[Johan Kjølstad]] (NOR) coming in second and third. [http://www.fis-ski.com/uk/604/610.html?sector=CC&raceid=7482 (FIS-Ski Results)] *[[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[College football|football]]: **The [[University of Southern California|USC Trojans]] guarantee themselves a spot in the national championship game with a 29–24 win over the [[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]] Bruins. [https://web.archive.org/web/20050404032829/http://sports.yahoo.com/ncaaf/recap?gid=200412040064 (AP)] **The [[University of Oklahoma|Oklahoma Sooners]], with a 42–3 rout of the [[University of Colorado at Boulder|Colorado Buffaloes]] in the [[Big 12 Conference|Big 12]] championship game, become USC's likely opponent in the [[Orange Bowl (game)|Orange Bowl]]. [https://sports.yahoo.com/ncaaf/boxscore?gid=200412040024 (AP)] **The [[Auburn University|Auburn Tigers]] win the [[Southeastern Conference|SEC]] championship by beating the [[University of Tennessee at Knoxville|Tennessee Volunteers]] 38–28. [https://sports.yahoo.com/ncaaf/recap?gid=200412040071 (AP)] **The [[Virginia Tech|Virginia Tech Hokies]] win the [[Atlantic Coast Conference|ACC]] title with a 16–10 win over the [[University of Miami|Miami Hurricanes]]. [https://sports.yahoo.com/ncaaf/recap?gid=200412040011 (AP)] **[[Tyler Palko]] throws five touchdowns to lead his [[University of Pittsburgh|Pittsburgh Panthers]] to a 43–14 win over the [[University of South Florida|USF Bulls]], assuring Pittsburgh a share of the [[Big East Conference (1979–2013)|Big East Conference]] title (along with [[Boston College]] and [[Syracuse University|Syracuse]]) and a spot in a [[Bowl Championship Series|BCS]] bowl. [https://sports.yahoo.com/ncaaf/recap?gid=200412041019 (AP)] **In the 105th [[Army–Navy Game]], quarterback [[Aaron Polanco]] passed for two touchdowns and scored another to lead [[United States Naval Academy|Navy]] to a 42–13 win. President [[George W. Bush]] was in attendance. [https://sports.yahoo.com/ncaaf/recap?gid=200412040102 (AP)] **The [[Capital One Bowl]] matchup for this year is announced: The [[University of Iowa|Iowa Hawkeyes]] will play the [[Louisiana State University|LSU Tigers]] on January 1 in [[Orlando, Florida]]. [https://sports.yahoo.com/ncaaf/news?slug=ap-capitalone-iowa&prov=ap&type=lgns (AP)]
==December 3, 2004== *[[Baseball]]: One day after revealing [[Jason Giambi]]'s admission of [[anabolic steroid]] use, the [[San Francisco Chronicle]] reports that [[San Francisco Giants]] slugger [[Barry Bonds]] had also admitted to taking designer drugs known as [[the cream]] and [[the clear]] in his [[grand jury]] testimony, but unlike Giambi, Bonds claimed he was unaware at the time that they contained steroids. [http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2004/baseball/mlb/12/03/bonds.steroids.ap/index.html (AP)] *[[Athletics (track and field)]]: [[Victor Conte]], the founder of [[Bay Area Laboratory Co-operative|BALCO]], says during a television interview that he personally saw United States sprinter [[Marion Jones]] inject [[human growth hormone]] into her body.[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2004/more/12/02/jones.steroids.ap/index.html (AP)] *[[National Basketball Association|NBA]]: The [[Detroit Pistons]] erase a 21-point lead by the [[San Antonio Spurs]], but the Spurs hang on for a close, 80–77 victory.[http://aol.nba.com/games/20041203/DETSAS/recap.html] **[[Corey Blount]] of the [[Boston Celtics]] blocks a shot by [[Vince Carter]] of the [[Toronto Raptors]] with five seconds to go, preserving the Celtics' 91–89 victory.[http://aol.nba.com/games/20041203/TORBOS/recap.html] **The [[Minnesota Timberwolves]] break the [[Phoenix Suns]]' eight-game winning streak, defeating them, 97–93.[http://aol.nba.com/games/20041203/MINPHO/recap.html]
==December 2, 2004== *[[Baseball]]: The ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' reports that [[New York Yankees]] [[first baseman]] [[Jason Giambi]] admitted to a [[grand jury]] that he took [[anabolic steroid|steroids]] made by [[Bay Area Laboratory Co-operative|BALCO]]. [https://sports.yahoo.com/mlb/news;_ylc=X3oDMTBpa2lpNnFzBF9TAzk1ODYxNzc3BHNlYwN0bQ--?slug=ap-giambi-steroids&prov=ap&type=lgns (AP)] [http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/news/story?id=1936592 (ESPN)] *[[National Basketball Association|NBA]]: [[Dirk Nowitzki]] of the [[Dallas Mavericks]] scores 53 points in a 113–106 [[Overtime (sports)|overtime]] win over the [[Houston Rockets]]. [[Tracy McGrady]] scores 49 points in a losing effort. [http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2004/basketball/nba/12/02/rockets.mavericks.ap/index.html (AP)] *[[Biathlon]]: In the opening event (WC 1) held at [[Øystre Slidre|Beitostølen]], Norway, of the 2004/05 Biathlon World Cup (BWC) season, the women's 7.5 km Sprint race is won by [[Uschi Disl]] (GER), with fellow German teammate [[Andrea Henkel]] catching the 2nd place, and [[Albina Akhatova]] (Албина Ахатова) (RUS) finishing 3rd. [http://biathlonworld.siwidata.info/data/archives.aspx?RaceId=BT0405SWRLCP01SWSP (IBU/EBU Results)] In the men's 10 km Sprint race, [[Ole Einar Bjørndalen]] (NOR) comes into his 44th BWC victory, followed by [[Nikolay Kruglov, Jr.]] (Николай Кругов) (RUS) and [[Raphaël Poirée]] (FRA) onto the next two places on the podium. [http://biathlonworld.siwidata.info/data/archives.aspx?RaceId=BT0405SWRLCP01SMSP (IBU/EBU Results)] *[[Cricket]]: [[India national cricket team|India]] beat [[South Africa national cricket team|South Africa]] by 8 wickets in the second [[Test cricket|test]] in [[Kolkata]], India to take the 2 test series 1–0. [http://uk.cricinfo.com/link_to_database/ARCHIVE/CRICKET_NEWS/2004/DEC/117367_INDRSA2004-05_02DEC2004.html (Cricinfo)] *[[Football (soccer)]]: **[[UEFA]] is preparing an investigation into suspicious [[betting patterns]] related to last night's [[UEFA Cup]] group stage match between [[Panionios NFC|Panionios]] and [[FC Dinamo Tbilisi|Dinamo Tbilisi]]. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/europe/4062519.stm (BBC)] **[[UEFA Cup]] Group Stage, Matchday 4 ***Group E: '''[[FK Partizan|Partizan Belgrade]]''' 1 – 1 '''[[Villarreal CF|Villarreal]]''' ***Group E: [[Egaleo FC|Egaleo]] 2 – 2 [[S.S. Lazio|Lazio]] ***Group F: '''[[AZ Alkmaar]]''' 1 – 0 [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] ***Group F: [[AJ Auxerre|Auxerre]] 5 – 1 [[Amica Wronki]] ***Group G: [[Dinamo Zagreb]] 2 – 2 [[SC Heerenveen|Heerenveen]] ***Group G: [[K.S.K. Beveren|Beveren]] 0 – 3 '''[[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]]''' ***Group H: '''[[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]]''' 3 – 2 [[AEK Athens F.C.|AEK Athens]] ***Group H: [[Alemannia Aachen|Alemannia]] 2 – 2 [[FC Zenit St Peterburg|Zenit St. Petersburg]] *** (Teams in '''bold''' are assured of progressing to the final round of 32 teams) [http://www.uefa.com/Competitions/UefaCup/index.html (UEFA.com)] *[[Ice hockey]]: For the first time in three months, the [[National Hockey League]] agrees to meet with the [[National Hockey League Players Association]]. The meeting will take place on December 9 in [[Toronto]], and it is believed the NHLPA will submit a new proposal in an effort to settle the [[2004–05 NHL lockout|ongoing lockout]]. [https://www.tsn.ca/nhl/news_story.asp?id=106699 (TSN)]
==December 1, 2004== *[[Football (soccer)]]: ** [[UEFA Cup]] group stage, Matchday 4 [http://www.uefa.com/competitions/UEFACup/FixturesResults/MD=6.html (UEFA.com)]: ***Group A: [[Ferencvárosi TC|Ferencváros]] 1 – 2 [[FC Basel|Basel]] ***Group A: '''[[Feyenoord Rotterdam|Feyenoord]]''' 2 – 1 '''[[FC Schalke 04|Schalke 04]]''' ***Group B: [[Athletic Bilbao]] 1 – 0 '''[[FC Steaua București|Steaua Bucharest]]''' ***Group B: [[Beşiktaş Jimnastik Kulübü|Beşiktaş]] 1 – 1 [[Standard Liège]] ***Group C: [[FK Austria Wien|Austria Vienna]] 1 – 1 [[Club Brugge]] ***Group C: [[Real Zaragoza]] 2 – 1 '''[[FC Dnipro Dnipropetrovsk|Dnipro]]''' ***Group D: [[Sporting Clube de Portugal|Sporting Lisbon]] 0 – 1 [[FC Sochaux-Montbéliard|Sochaux]] ***Group D: [[Panionios NFC|Panionios]] 5 – 2 [[FC Dinamo Tbilisi|Dinamo Tbilisi]] *** (Teams in '''bold''' are assured of progressing to the final round of 32 teams) ** [[Asian Champions League|AFC Champions League]]: [[Al-Ittihad (Jeddah)|Al-Ittihad]] of [[Saudi Arabia]] wins the title, 6–3 on aggregate, over [[Ilhwa chunma|Seongnam Ilhwa Chunma]] of [[South Korea]]. Al-Ittihad trailed 3–1 after the first leg in Saudi Arabia, but wins 5–0 in the return leg in South Korea. [http://www.the-afc.com/english/media/default.asp?mnaction=news&action=details&newsID=960 (Asian Football Confederation)]

page.title: El Salvador at the 1984 Summer Olympics

revision.text:
{{infobox country at games | NOC = ESA | NOCname = [[El Salvador Olympic Committee]] | games = Summer Olympics | year = 1984 | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = {{url|www.teamesa.org }} {{es icon}} | location = [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]] | competitors = 10 (9 men and 1 woman) | sports = 5 | flagbearer = [[Kriscia García]] | rank = | gold = 0 | silver = 0 | bronze = 0 | officials = | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = | app_end_year = | summerappearances = | winterappearances = | seealso = }} '''[[El Salvador]]''' competed at the '''[[1984 Summer Olympics]]''' in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], [[United States]], from 28 July to 12 August 1984. This was the nation's third appearance at the Olympics. The nation previously missed the [[1976 Summer Olympics]] and participated in the [[1980 Summer Olympics boycott]]. Comité Olímpico de El Salvador sent a total of 10 athletes to the Games, 9 men and 1 women, to compete in 5 sports. Long-distance runner [[Kriscia García]] was chosen to carry her nation's flag during the opening ceremony. == Competitors == Comité Olímpico de El Salvador selected a team of 10 athletes, 9 men and 1 women, to compete in 5 sports.[https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/countries/ESA/summer/1984/ "El Salvador at the 1984 Los Angeles Summer Games."] Sports-Reference.com. Retrieved on 18 March 2014. Trap shooter [[Julio González (sport shooter)|Julio González]], at age 40, was the oldest athlete of the team, while swimmer [[Juan Miranda (swimmer)|Juan Miranda]] was the youngest at age 16. The following is the list of number of competitors participating in the Games. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center; font-size:90%;" ! width=80|Sport ! width=40|Men ! width=40|Women ! width=40|Total |- | align=left|[[Athletics at the 1984 Summer Olympics|Athletics]] | 3 || 1 || 4 |- | align=left|[[Judo at the 1984 Summer Olympics|Judo]] | 2 || 0 || 2 |- | align=left|[[Shooting at the 1984 Summer Olympics|Shooting]] | 1 || 0 || 1 |- | align=left|[[Swimming at the 1984 Summer Olympics|Swimming]] | 2 || 0 || 2 |- | align=left|[[Wrestling at the 1984 Summer Olympics|Wrestling]] | 1 || 0 || 1 |- class="sortbottom" ! {{Infobox stadium | name = Estadio Victor Della Valle | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = | caption = | fullname = | former_names = | location = [[Carrasco, Montevideo|Carrasco]], [[Montevideo]], [[Uruguay]] | coordinates = {{Coord|34|52|20.46|S|56|3|26.37|W|scale:3125_region:UY|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = {{Start date|1983|06|01}} | built = | opened = {{Start date|1992|06|28}} | renovated = 2010 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[El Tanque Sisley]] | operator = | surface = grass | scoreboard = | cost = 250,000 [[US dollars]] | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 6,000 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = [[El Tanque Sisley]] | embedded = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> }} The '''Estadio Victor Della Valle''' is a [[association football|football]] stadium in [[Montevideo]], [[Uruguay]] with a capacity of 6,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldstadiums.com/south_america/countries/uruguay.shtml |title=Stadiums in Uruguay|publisher=Worldstadiums.com|accessdate=21 September 2011}}</ref> It is the home stadium of [[El Tanque Sisley]], a team in the [[Uruguayan Primera División]].

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Use South African English|date=January 2018}} The '''Gauteng Province Australian Football League''' is an [[Australian rules football]] competition in [[South Africa]] operating out of the province of [[Gauteng]].
==History== The league began with Eldorado Park (the Eldos), formed by a development officer in 2002. In 2003, a club from [[Pretoria]] was formed. Teams from [[Johannesburg]] and [[RAU University]] were included in 2004.
==Clubs== *Eldorado Park *RAU University *Johannesburg *Pretoria
==See also== *[[AFL South Africa]]
[[Category:Australian rules football in South Africa]] [[Category:Sport in Gauteng]]
{{AFL-competition-stub}} {{SouthAfrica-sport-stub}}

{{Malay name|Hanif|Hamir}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Hanif Hamir | fullname = Muhammad Hanif @ Abdul Hadi bin Hamir | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1997|2|22|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Brunei]] | height = {{convert|1.84|m|ftin|abbr=on}} | position = [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|Centre-back]] | currentclub = [[DPMM FC]] | clubnumber = 24 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = [[Brunei Sports School|Sports School]] | youthyears2 = 2015 | youthclubs2 = [[DPMM FC|DPMM U19]] | years1 = 2014 | caps1 = | goals1 = 0| clubs1 = [[Najip I-Team|Najip FC]] | years2 = 2015 | caps2 = | goals2 = 0| clubs2 = [[Tabuan Muda|Tabuan U18]] | years3 = 2015–2016 | caps3 = | goals3 = 1| clubs3 = [[Tabuan Muda]] | years4 = 2017– | caps4 = 12| goals4 = 0| clubs4 = [[DPMM FC]] | nationalyears1= 2014– | nationalcaps1= 1 | nationalgoals1= 0 | nationalteam1= [[Brunei national under-21 football team|Brunei U21]] | nationalyears2= 2015– | nationalcaps2= 5 | nationalgoals2= 0 | nationalteam2= [[Brunei national under-23 football team|Brunei U23]] | nationalyears3= 2015 | nationalcaps3= 5 | nationalgoals3= 0 | nationalteam3= [[Brunei national under-19 football team|Brunei U19]] | nationalyears4= 2015– | nationalcaps4= 6 | nationalgoals4= 0 | nationalteam4= [[Brunei national football team|Brunei]] | club-update = 16 August 2018 | ntupdate = 27 March 2017 }}
'''Muhammad Hanif [[Alias name|@]] Abdul Hadi bin Hamir''' (born 22 February 1997) is a [[Brunei]]an international [[Association football|footballer]] who plays professionally for [[DPMM FC]] as a [[Defender (association football)|defender]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Nat’l team on right track|url=http://www.bruneiolympic.org/?t=news/index&p=news/2016/20160202a|date=2 February 2015|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref> Already the first-choice centre-back for his country at international level, Hanif represents the future of [[Football in Brunei|Bruneian football]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Rosmin wants focus, concentration |url=http://bruneifootball.blogspot.com/2016/10/rosmin-wants-focus-concentration.html|date=13 October 2016|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref>
==Club career== Hanif is a graduate of Brunei's [[Brunei Sports School|Sports School]], the institution that also produced Bruneian internationals such as [[Azwan Ali Rahman]] and [[Shafie Effendy]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Sports School opening enrollment|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/147018841@N07/31544551081/in/album-72157673926094104/|date=20 January 2016|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref> He began his league football career with [[Najip FC]] in 2014, a team that [[2012-13 Brunei Super League|lost every game in their previous season]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Najip FC looking to start afresh this season|url=http://www.nfabd.org/news/2014012102.htm|date=21 January 2014|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref> Coached by the late [[Johari Bungsu]], Hanif achieved a third-place finish with Najip FC in the [[2014 Brunei Super League]] and also reached the final of the FA Cup that season, scoring the winner in the semi-final along the way.<ref>{{cite web |title=Najip FC enters the DST FA 2014 Finals |url=http://www.rtbnews.rtb.gov.bn/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=24668%3Anajip-fc-enters-the-dst-fa-2014-finals&Itemid=106|date=25 December 2014|publisher=Radio Televisyen Brunei|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref>
Brunei's football association [[National Football Association of Brunei Darussalam|NFABD]] created [[Tabuan Muda]] in 2015, a league team that serves to prepare for international tournaments, mirroring [[Singapore national football team|Singapore's]] [[Young Lions FC|Young Lions]] and [[Malaysia national football team|Malaysia's]] [[Harimau Muda]] teams.<ref>{{cite web |title=Season starts next week |url=http://bruneifootball.blogspot.com/2015/03/season-starts-next-week.html|date=25 March 2015|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref> Hanif was assigned to the Under-18s playing in the [[Brunei Premier League]] at the start of the season,<ref>{{cite web |title=Najip start season with a win|url=http://www.nfabd.org/news/2015040402.htm|date=4 April 2015|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref> however he was promoted to the [[Brunei Super League]] team in the second half of the season.<ref>{{cite web |title=Tabuan Muda|url=http://nfabd.org/schedules/dst-superleague-2015-teams-06.htm|date=|publisher=National Football Association of Brunei Darussalam|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref> Tabuan Muda finished fifth in the [[2015 Brunei Super League|2015]] and [[2016 Brunei Super League|2016]] seasons of the BSL.
Hanif trialled out for and joined [[Brunei DPMM FC]]'s Under-19 team in early 2015.<ref>{{cite web |title=DPMM FC Under-19 team thrash BSSSA 11-0|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/147018841@N07/31672658006/in/album-72157677869971436/|date=7 September 2015|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref> Although he was overlooked for promotion in 2016, he was handed a professional contract by [[Steve Kean]] to play for DPMM in the [[S.League]] in [[2017 S.League|2017]]. He signed full terms on 15 January.<ref>{{cite web |title=DPMM FC finalise squad for new S League season|url=http://borneobulletin.com.bn/dpmm-fc-finalise-squad-new-s-league-season/|date=16 February 2017|publisher=Borneo Bulletin|accessdate=16 February 2017}}</ref> He made his debut in the 4–0 loss against [[Albirex Niigata Singapore FC|Albirex Niigata FC (S)]] on 16 June.<ref>{{cite web |title=DPMM FC lose to Albirex as slump continues|url=https://www.brusports.com/2017/06/17/dpmm-fc-lose-to-albirex-as-slump-continues/|date=17 June 2017|publisher=BruSports News|accessdate=20 June 2017}}</ref>
==International career==
Hanif has been playing for the [[Brunei national football team|national team]] and its various youth teams since 2014. His youth tournaments include the [[2014 Hassanal Bolkiah Trophy]] for [[Brunei national under-21 football team|Under-21]], the [[Football at the 2015 Southeast Asian Games – Group B|28th SEA Games]] for [[Brunei national under-23 football team|Under-23]], the [[2015 AFF U-19 Youth Championship]] and the [[2016 AFC U-19 Championship qualification]] with the [[Brunei national under-19 football team|Under-19s]].
Hanif was called up to the national team for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification – AFC First Round|2018 World Cup qualifiers]] against [[Chinese Taipei national football team|Chinese Taipei]] in March 2015.<ref>{{cite web |title=Brunei team to meet Chinese Taipei named|url=http://borneobulletin.com.bn/brunei-team-meet-chinese-taipei-named/|date=6 March 2015|publisher=Borneo Bulletin|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref> He started both games at centre-back in a 1-2 aggregate loss which eliminated Brunei from the [[2018 World Cup]].
Hanif played in a 6-1 drubbing by [[Cambodia national football team|Cambodia]] in a friendly on 3 November 2015.<ref>{{cite web |title=Cambodia put six goals past Brunei in friendly|url=http://borneobulletin.com.bn/cambodia-put-six-goals-past-brunei-in-friendly/|date=4 November 2015|publisher=Borneo Bulletin|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref> His next callup was at the [[2016 AFF Suzuki Cup qualification]] matches held in [[Cambodia]] in October, and started all three matches. He missed out on the [[2016 AFC Solidarity Cup]] squad a fortnight later due to injury.<ref>{{cite web |title=Kwon positive despite defensive woe|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/147018841@N07/31667158486/in/album-72157676332530221/|date=30 October 2016|publisher=The Brunei Times|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref>
In 2017, Hanif was announced as one of Brunei's athletes for the year's [[2017 Southeast Asian Games|SEA Games]] football tournament held in Malaysia in August, playing with the under-23s.<ref>{{cite web |title=105 athletes named to represent Brunei at 29th SEA Games|url=https://www.brusports.com/2017/07/29/105-athletes-named-to-represent-brunei-at-29th-sea-games/|date=29 July 2017|publisher=BruSports News|accessdate=14 August 2017}}</ref> However he was replaced by [[Nadzri Erwan]] on the eve of the biennial sporting event.<ref>https://www.kualalumpur2017.com.my/seagames-athlete.cshtml?cid=1</ref>
